column6: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 09 October - 05 November. A Lendu militia attacked the FARDC in Jiro.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 09 October - 05 November. A Lendu militia attacked the FARDC in Muvaramu.
On Oct 23, a man was killed in Biriko village in Walikale territory by the Mai-Mai Kifuafua Delphin militia.
Around 23 October 2018 (as reported), a man was assassinated by presumed ADF rebels in his fields and found by locals in Masosi quarter in Oicha (Beni, Nord-Kivu).

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 23 October 2018, after finding a lifeless body in their fields, locals tried to alert nearby soldiers to investigate in Masosi quarter (Beni, Nord-Kivu). They refused to attend the scene, so the youth took up the body to walk with it and police intervened by shooting at them with bullets. No fatalities or injuries reported. [size=no report]

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 24 Oct 2018, ADF militiamen attacked Bakaiku neighborhood of Oicha rural commune. They killed three people and burned houses and vehicles before being repelled by the FARDC. The attackers also looted goats, drugs and other property.
On 24 October 2018, presumed ADF fighters burnt three vehicles and eight homes in Maendeleo in Oicha commune (Beni, Nord-Kivu), pillaging the homes before burning them.

column8: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: 24 October. ADF forces attacked the MONUSCO base at Semliki bridge (assumed to be in Beni based on river location and ADF area of activity). Peacekeepers repelled the attackers.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 24 October 2018, FARDC clashed with an unidentified armed group in Mbelu locality, 5km northeast of Beni city (Beni, Nord-Kivu). No fatalities or injuries reported.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 25 October (on or around). At the end of October, the FARDC clashed with the FNL in the Butole area.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 25 October (on or around). At the end of October, FARDC forces clashed with the FNL in the Muramvya highlands of Uvira.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 25 October 2018, a group of youths tried to attack a house they thought housed Rwandans affiliated with the ADF in Kasabinyole quarter in Beni city (Beni, Nord-Kivu). The police intervened and shot two civilians. It is not clear if they died. [size=no report]

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Around 25 October 2018 (between 25 - 26 October), a soldier was killed in his home by unknown armed men in Rwenzori district (Beni, Nord-Kivu).

On Oct 26, a peaceful protests was organized in Kinshasa by the main opposition parties. The protest followed a call by the opposition to ask for the cancellation of voting machines and the revision of electoral lists ahead of the upcoming elections.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Oct 26 the FARDC attacked a Mayi Mayi position in Kabare. In the clashes 5 soldiers and five militiamen were killed, other two FARDC soldiers were injured.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Oct 26, protesters were dispersed in Mbuji Mayi. The protests followed a call by the opposition to ask for the cancellation of voting machines and the revision of electoral lists ahead of the upcoming elections.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Oct 26, clashes reported between protesters and police in Lubumbashi. The protest followed a call by the opposition to ask for the cancellation of voting machines and the revision of electoral lists ahead of the upcoming elections.

On Oct 26, peaceful protests were reported in Goma. The protests followed a call by the opposition to ask for the cancellation of voting machines and the revision of electoral lists ahead of the upcoming elections.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: 28-30 October: Three days of clashes between FARDC and FRPI militiamen in Walendu Bindi chieftaincy, south of Bunia. At least two FARDC soldiers died in clashes (spread over three days of fighting).

column7: UNC: Union for the Congolese Nation
column17: A peaceful protest accompanied the nomination of the UNC candidate, in the district of Lukunga, in in the commune of Mont-Ngafula on the Ntumba field.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Around 28 October 2018 (between 28 - 29 October), six FARDC soldiers extorted money from a patisserie shop fleeing upon the arrival of police in Oicha (Beni, Nord-Kivu).
On Oct 28, six people died during an ADF raid in Makumbo village. Other sources reported eight fatalities. The assailants also abducted two civilians.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: 29 October. Clashes continued between FARDC and FRPI militiamen in Walendu Bindi chieftaincy, with the forces clashing in Burasi. At least two FARDC soldiers died in clashes (spread over three days of fighting).

On 29 October 2018, residents of Tamende neighbourhood in Beni city (Beni, Nord-Kivu) burned down the home of the suspected murderer of a woman. The house along with the contents were destroyed. [size=no report]

column8: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column17: 29 October. The NDC-Renove clashed with the APCLS in Bwenderu (coordinates are approximate based on location 32 km west of Kitchanga). The local population fled the area.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: 30 October. Clashes continued between FARDC and FRPI militiamen in Walendu Bindi chieftaincy, in Kigo village (no coordinates available). At least two FARDC soldiers died in clashes (spread over three days of fighting).

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Oct 30, FARDC clashed with Mayi Mayi Mutomboki-Blaise militia in the Ninja chieftaincy, Kabare territory. 33 deaths have been confirmed. Some NGOs have reported the death of civilians among the victims but this was not confirmed by the army.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 30 October. The FARDC clashed with the FRPI in Geti.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: Oct 30, FRPI militiamen looted property in Upili locality and stole cattle south of Irumu, amidst clashes with the military in Walendu Bindi chieftaincy, south of Bunia.

On Oct 30, workers from the FAB Congo organized a protest in front of the Kinshasa town hall to demand the reopening of their company, in accordance with the decision of the prosecutor's office of Matete.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Oct 30, a young girl was abducted and raped by an armed men dressed in military uniform near Kiringa village in Rutshuru territory.

column7: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column17: 30 October. Military forces of Burundi and Imbonerakure were seen crossing the border from Gasenyi in Burundi into the DRC, where they set up camp with FARDC forces (coded as Uvira prec3). They are preparing an offensive against Burundian rebels from Red Tabara in eastern DRC. Locals reported that Rwandans were also with the security forces in Burundi, although the military has denied this.

column9: Refugees/IDPs (Democratic Republic of Congo); Teachers (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Oct 31, about 10 IDPs, including teachers, were abducted by Reformed Nduma Defence of the Congo militia combatants led by Guidon in Kilambo, Bafuni region, Masisi territory.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Oct 31, miners expressed their anger to authorities after finding the body of one of their colleagues five days after he disappeared and started looting shops and damaging and burning vehicles. They threw stones at police and soldiers deployed to restore calm in the area, who in turn fired gunshots.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 31 October. The FARDC clashed with the FRPI in Kamasuka (coordinates are approximate based on location 5 km north of Geti).

column17: On 31 Oct 2018, unidentified gunmen fired bullets into the house of a National Intelligence Agency (ANR) agent at Kahira village in Masisi territory. Two people were killed, including the ANR agent, and two others wounded.

column6: FDLR-RUD: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda-Rally for Unity and Democracy
column17: On Oct 31, a man was shot dead by FDLR-RUD in Nyamirambo village in Rutshuru territory.

On Oct 31, clashes were reported in Bundje village in Kalehe territory between Mai-Mai Kirikicho and the Mai-Mai Kabishula. They resulted in the death of one and wounded another Mai-Mai Kabishula fighter.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 31 October 2018, a boutique was vandalised by FARDC soldiers who took away a large amount of money in Beni city (Beni, Nord-Kivu).

column8: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column17: On Oct 31, clashes erupted between Guidon Muisa's NDC militia and Janvier Kalairi's APCLS in Kalungu locality, Bashali Mokoto area, Masisi territory. At least 4 people died in the clashes: one APCLS militia combatant and three NCDR members.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Oct 31, the youth president of the Salongo district of Bunia (Ituri), was kidnapped. He was found on November 2 in a state of unconsciousness.

column8: RED-TABARA: Resistance to the Rule of Law in Burundi
column17: Between October 2018 and November 2018 [coded to 1 November 2018], near Kabere, armed clashes between the FDN and Imbonerakure against RED Tabara occurred.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

On Nov 2, journalists demonstrated in Kinshasa demanding the release of their colleague Peter Tiani, prosecuted for ""defamation"" against the Prime Minister and held for three days.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column17: On Nov 2, the newly appointed ANR (National Intelligence Agency) agent and his wife were killed in their house by an unknown group of men while two other occupants of the house escaped unhurt in Tambi.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: UPLC: Union of Patriots for the Liberation of Congo
column17: 02 November. The FARDC launched operations against UPLC forces in Kasyiro.
On Nov 2, teachers demonstrated in Beni against the insecurity in the region. They accused MONUSCO and FARDC of not working effectively to prevent ADF attacks.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 2 Nov 2018, FARDC soldiers killed three men and wounded another in Mambangu village in Lubero territory. They also looted property.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column17: On Nov 2, clashes were reported in in the villages of Kahololo, Muhanga, Butumba and Mashuba in Uvira territory when Unidentified gunmen attacked RED TABARA positions. These clashes resulted in one dead and six wounded for the attackers.

column17: On Nov 2, clashes were reported in in the villages of Kahololo, Muhanga, Butumba and Mashuba in Uvira territory when Unidentified gunmen attacked RED TABARA positions. These clashes resulted in one dead and six wounded for the attackers.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Nov 2, Mai-Mai Kihebe and Kigjangala positions in the villages of Lushago and Kiridja in Uvira territory were attacked by unidentified gunmen. At least 59 houses were burned but there are no further information about causalities.
On Nov 2, Isopo village in Mwenga territory was raided by the Raia Mutomboki Ndarumanga . They looted money, livestock and property. They also abducted three men to carry the looted goods.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column17: On Nov 2, clashes were reported in in the villages of Kahololo, Muhanga, Butumba and Mashuba in Uvira territory when Unidentified gunmen attacked RED TABARA positions. These clashes resulted in one dead and six wounded for the attackers.

Around 2 November 2018 (as reported), a man was found dead in Masulukwede village in Beni territory (Beni, Nord-Kivu) following any earlier attack by ADF rebels. Another man was found near Mamundioma locality, after going to his field. His death was also attributed to ADF rebels.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Around 2 November 2018 (between 2 - 3 November), Mayi Mayi militiamen attacked a military garrison to liberate those previously detained in Beni city (Beni, Nord-Kivu). About 30 were liberated. No fatalities or injuries reported.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Nov 3, 4 and 5, unidentified gunmen attacked the Mugunga, Utchukpa and Muvaramu military bases in Djugu territory (Ituri). Seven soldiers dead and several civilians (estimated total of 17). Fatalities are disaggregated in the three events.
On Nov 3, three people were killed and several others were wounded in an incursion of presumed ADF in Mbau in the Beni territory.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 3 Nov 2018, the FARDC intercepted and attacked the Raia Mutomboki Ndarumanga who had just raided Isopo village in Mwenga territory. Seven Raia Mutomboki Ndarumanga fighters and one hostage were killed.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Nov 3, the Nyatura Domi attacked the FARDC in Mashango village in Rutshuru territory. The Nyatura killed five FARDC soldiers and stole weapons.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Nov 3, unidentified assailants raided Sake village in Masisi territory, clashing with the FARDC. One FARDC soldier and four civilians were killed while six people were wounded.

column6: UPLC: Union of Patriots for the Liberation of Congo
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) Prison Guards
column17: On Nov 3, the Mai-Mai Kilalo attacked the military prosecutor's office in the Cite-Belge neighbourhood of Beni town. The FARDC guards fired but did not resist the assault. The attackers managed to release 35 detainees. An FARDC soldier was reported missing.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Nov 3, a man was shot dead by unidentified gunmen in the Kabindula neighbourhood of the rural Uvira commune.
On 3 Nov 2018, the ADF targeted two vehicles near Sikwaila village in Beni territory, killing eight people. The attackers also burned a vehicle.

On Nov 3, clashes were reported when The Raia Mutomboki Kabishula attacked the Mai-Mai Kirikicho at Tushunguti village in Kalehe territory. The attack left three dead and one wounded on the Mai-Mai Kirikicho's side, and one dead and one wounded on the Raia Mutomboki Kabishula's side.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 3 Nov 2018, unidentified assailants raided Iseke village of Mwenga territory, shooting and killing a young man. They also looted money, livestock and property.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

On Nov 4, ADF militiamen attacked Oicha, killing one person and abducting 15 others,
On Nov 4, ADF militiamen attacked the village of Mangboko, in Beni, where they burnt a lorry driver in his vehicle and killed another six civilians.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Nov 5, a FARDC soldier was killed by the Nyatura Domi in Kiseghe village in Rutshuru territory. The attackers stole the weapon of the killed soldier.
On Nov 7, some members from a civil society group called VICI (Vigilance Citoyenne) marched asking the release of 17 members arrested at the beginning of the year.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

The soldiers attempted to flee by firing at the youths. [size=no report]

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: On 5 November 2018, a FARDC soldier was injured during a clash with a Mayi Mayi militiaman with a machete in Viski region of Beni territory (Beni, Nord-Kivu).

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 5 Nov 2018, during a row between fishermen and state agents at Cikumbo village in Idjwi territory, a police officer shot and seriously wounded a man. The victim later died in Bukavu hospital.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Nov 3, 4 and 5, unidentified gunmen attacked the Mugunga, Utchukpa and Muvaramu military bases in Djugu territory (Ituri). Seven soldiers dead and several civilians (estimated total of 17). Fatalities are disaggregated in the three events.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On June 11 the FARDC attacked the Nyatura led by Niyonzimana (also known as Forces de Defense du Peuple - FDP) after an alert concerning their presence was given in Rutshuru. The clash lasted 2 hours.
On Nov 6, Butembo health workers peacefully demonstrated denouncing the multiple attacks that they claim to be victims of since the eruption of the Ebola epidemic last August in the region.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: On 6 November 2018, an armed clash occurred between ADF rebels and FARDC soldiers near PK 9 in Beni territory (Beni, Nord-Kivu). No fatalities or injuries reported.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Nov 7 some unknown gunmen attacked a FARDC position at Ndombi village in Beni territory. The attack resulted in the death of two FARDC soldiers.

column17: On 7 November 2018, presumed Mayi Mayi militiamen attacked, injured and kidnapped five Ebola health workers while they were burying an Ebola victim near Kahongera village (Beni, Nord-Kivu). They were released a few hours later.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 7 November 2018, students gathered at the Bungulu ""30th of June"" roundabout in Beni city (Beni, Nord-Kivu) to denounce the desensitization of the Beni population to violence. Altogether, four demonstrators were stopped and arrested by police for revolting against local authorities. [size=at least four]

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 7 November 2018, a Mayi Mayi militia attacked the positions of the FARDC in three villages including Mambabio (Beni, Nord-Kivu). During which 3 people were injured and 2 killed. Fatalities coded across two events.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 7 November 2018, a Mayi Mayi militia attacked the positions of the FARDC in three villages including Kamboka and Maitatu villages in Beni territory (Beni, Nord-Kivu). 3 people were injured and 2 killed. Fatalities coded across two events.

column6: Lemera Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Nov 7, clashes between Mayi-Mayi militiamen and vigilante youth of Lemera. After the fighting, Mayi Mayi set 50 houses on fire in Mushago and Kirinja and looted these two villages.
On or around Nov 7, after clashes between Mayi-Mayi militiamen and vigilante youth of Lemera, Mayi Mayi set 50 houses on fire in Mushago and Kirinja and looted these two villages.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 07 November. Mayi Mayi forces attacked the FARDC in Chani-Chani (no coordinates available) and Baoba (no coordinates available), in the Mayi Moya area.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Nov 7, seventeen militiamen led by Kawai Dewayo in Kasai were killed and others captured in an army ambush.
On Nov 8, Burundi forces and FNL militiamen clashed in Mulenge.

On Nov 8, students from all universities and higher institutions in the city of Goma initiated a peaceful march this in solidarity with those of Beni who are on strike following the recurrent massacres in this part of the province of North Kivu.

column6: FDLR-RUD: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda-Rally for Unity and Democracy
column17: On Nov 8, three women were kidnapped by FDLR-RUD combatants from the Buturande district of the Kiwanja rural commune. They raped two women and demanded a ransom for the release of the hostages.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Nov 8, the FARDC exchanged fire with a group of armed robbers robbing a minibus.

column17: On Nov 9, a man was kidnapped by unknown armed men from Mangoyo village (a few km north of Bingo - approx. coordinates used) in Beni territory.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Nov 9, the FARDC attacked the Mai-Mai Reunion, which had just looted cattle and goods from Ngalula village in the territory of Fizi.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 9 November 2018, a pastor was abducted by unknown armed men from his home in Bingo locality (Beni, Nord-Kivu). A ransom notice was sent.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 09 November. Suspected ADF fighters attacked a FARDC base in Silimbamba (coordinates are approximate, based on location 40 km north-east of Beni). Six soldiers were killed.

column6: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 09 November. A suspected Lendu militia attacked Landjo, and clashed with the FARDC. Nine soldiers were killed and 16 others sustained injuries.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Nov 10, unknown gunmen killed two adults and their three children in Boikene neighborhood of Beni town. The attackers also burned houses, a car and other property and looted farm animals.

Around 10 November 2018 (between 10 - 11 November), an incursion of presumed ADF rebels in Mayimoya village (Beni, Nord-Kivu) resulting in the death of five people including a pastor, the kidnapping of three children, and the hospitalization of another individual.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column9: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: Around 10 November 2018 (between 10 - 11 November), presumed ADF rebels attacked Boikene quarter (Beni, Nord-Kivu), burning down the MONUSCO base. Two people were killed during the clash and many others kidnapped. Belongings such as goats were taken and cars were burned. Locals attempted to chase the attackers with FARDC soldiers but were stopped.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Nov 11, a man was killed with a machete in his field at Kituva village near Kabase in Masisi territory by unidentified men.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Nov 11, a woman and a man were kidnapped by unidentified gunmen from the Mabanga neighborhood in Goma town. The kidnappers demanded a ransom of $20000 for the release of the hostages.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Nov 11, Mayi-Mayi attacked the FARDC position in Paida. They were repulsed by loyalist forces.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Mbororo Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Nov 12, four miners were killed while they were on their way back from the mines when they fell into an ambush laid by eight Mbororo herders.

10 November. A Raia Mutomboki group abducted four women from Nzovu. They held the women for three days, during which time they were raped. The presence of child soldiers - including eight year old girls - suggests the attackers belonged to the Raia Mutomboki Kokodikoko.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Nov 12, a student was killed during demonstrations against teachers' strike in Kinshasa.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Nov 13, three men were kidnapped from the Mangina district of the Mangina rural commune by unknown armed men.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 13 Nov 2018, an FARDC soldier shot and seriously wounded a man at Kimuka village in Uvira territory. The victim succumbed to his injuries in Bukavu.

On Nov 14, a dozen deaths were recorded in clashes between Burundian soldiers and Burundian rebels of the National Forces for Liberation (FNL) in Uvira and Fizi, in the province of South Kivu. FARDC sources said Wednesday (14 November) that a total of sixteen people were killed in the fighting. Fatalities are disaggregated in the two events (36,37)

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: On 14 November 2018, in Kididiwe, joint FARDC-MONUSCO troops recaptured a former FARDC camp from ADF militiamen. During the operation, 7 United Nations peacekeepers were killed and 10 wounded, while 2 were still missing in action. FARDC reported that 14  soldiers had been killed, 29 had been wounded and 12 were still missing in action. An estimated 40 to 50 ADF combatants were killed.

column9: PPRD: Peoples Party for Reconstruction and Democracy
column17: During the week of Nov 12th, two PPRD candidates in the legislative elections in Dibaya were kidnapped by armed men led by the militia leader Tshiyoyo.
15 November. The LRA attacked Pasi. The group looted the village and abducted four men, a woman and a baby. They later released the woman and child.
On Nov 15, ADF militiamen attacked the city of Beni killing 5 people and burning many houses of the village.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: ""Two INGO staff members were killed in an ambush while travelling by motorcycle between Fatuma and Maendeleo village along the Kalemie-Moba road axis. The bodies were recovered and brought back to Kalemie on November 17th, 2018. The means of attack consisted of bodily assault by stabbing and shooting. It is currently unknown who the perpetrators were and what the motive was for the attack.""
On Nov 15, students violently demonstrated in front of the University in Kinshasa for the death of one of their fellows.
On 15 November 2018, presumed ADF rebels ambushed a Jeep travelling in Mukoko village (Beni, Nord-Kivu) and killed two women. Other occupants of the Jeep are still unfound.
On 15 November 2018, presumed ADF rebels attacked civilians in Mambanike-Moba quarter in Oicha (Beni, Nord-Kivu). They killed 5 people, and burnt down and looted dozens of houses.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column9: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: On 15 November 2018, FARDC and MONUSCO clashed with the ADF in Mayangose zone in Boikene quarter (Beni, Nord-Kivu). 7 peacekeepers (6 Malawians and 1 Tanzanian) and 12 soldiers were killed during the clash.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Mbororo Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Nov 15, miners in Dikuma, a locality of Ango territory, some 500 km north of Kisangani rose up against the death of 5 miners. The Mbororo herders sought refuge in the FARDC camp in Bweli. FARDC managed to restore order.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 15 November 2018, at PK 13 road near Mbau, an unidentified armed group clashed with FARDC resulting in 1 FARDC killed and 3 injured.

On Nov 16, two fishermen were shot and wounded by the Mai-Mai Charles on Lake Edward near Mulindi village in Rutshuru territory (approx. coordinates). The victims had requested an extension for the payment of a tax imposed by the militiamen. One of the wounded succumbed to his injuries.

On 16 November 2018, alleged ADF rebels attacked civilians after they crossed the Niglingili in the Tenambo locality (Beni, Nord-Kivu) to reach Mobaii. They attacked the village killing 4 civilians, injuring 3 and looting businesses, while also burning down 17 houses.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-) National Intelligence Agency; Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: On 16 November 2018, FARDC soldiers, ANR agents and police attacked civilians in Kikura (Beni, Nord-Kivu). Two men were beaten to death and others were tied up all night.

column9: Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: On 16 November 2018, presumed ADF rebels attacked Boikene quarter (Beni, Nord-Kivu), damaging university buildings and home of the Chief. Fires were set and cars burned. No fatalities or injuries reported.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On November 16, a student was killed during clashes with police. The students were protesting the death of one of them, on the same campus, earlier this week.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: On the evening of November 16, a UN base 7 km north of the city of Beni was attacked by ADF militiamen.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Nov 17, the home of FDLR-FOCA fighter was attacked by unidentified gunmen at Bugomba village in Rutshuru territory. The attackers killed the said commander.

On 18 November 2018, presumed ADF rebels ambushed those travelling along the n 4 between Eringeti and Oicha at Mukoko village (Beni, Nord-Kivu). Two women were reportedly killed and two vehicles burnt.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Nov 18, a soldier attacked a congregation of mourners, shooting dead five people and injuring ten others in Tshikapa the Kasai region in the central DRC.

column9: Mataba Communal Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 19 November 2018, a local chief was attacked by Mayi Mayi militiamen before being kidnapped in Mataba village (Beni, Nord-Kivu).

On Nov 19, the Raia Mutomboki Kazimoto looted 200 kilograms of cassiterite money from AGEFRECO transport agents near Lukala village in Shabunda territory. The attackers forced ten men to carry the looted goods.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Nov 19, students from the University of Kinshasa demonstrated, giving the government 48 hours to resume classes. Police used tear gas, students respond with stones and other projectiles.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Nov 20, three political activists were killed by unknown armed men while canvassing for DR Congo's pro-government presidential candidate Emmanuel Ramazani Shadary.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 20 November. An armed group with AK 47's ambushed three men on a motorcycle in Lika. One of the men was severely injured. The attackers stole money and valuables from the men.

column8: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo

On 20 Nov 2018, Rwanda Defence Force (RDF) soldiers seriously wounded a civilian man on Lake Kivu near Birhalihale village in Idjwi territory. The victim later succumbed to his injuries in Goma hospital.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 21 November 2018, a Mayi Mayi militia attacked the FARDC base in Tsani Tsani in Bambuba Kisiki locality (Beni, Nord-Kivu), wherein two militiamen were killed.

column17: On November 22, near Kamango town (Oicha, Nord-Kivu), a helicopter from the UN mission was shot by Ugandan Muslim rebel (ADF) fire. There were no reported fatalities.

column6: Basengele Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Banunu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 22 November 2018, in Inongo territory [coded to Ibanda], violent clashes between the Basengele and Banunu communities have been reported.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 22 November 2018, near the Semuliki Bridge, an unidentified armed group attacked civilians (no further details available).

column17: On 23 November 2018, presumed ADF rebels attacked and clashed with MONUSCO troops in Massiani district in Boikene quarter (Beni, Nord-Kivu), killed one civilian and injured one civilian and one MONUSCO soldier, while also looting animals and valuable goods.

On November 26, in Beni city (Beni, Nord-Kivu), residents staged a protest against the ADF attack on Oicha town hours earlier.

On 26 November 2018, at PK 5 road near Mbau, ADF attacked civilians, killing 2.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On November 26, in Ruashi town (Lubumbashi, Katanga), residents staged a protest against the lack of electrical power for several days by barricading roads and burning tires. Congolese police intervened to disperse the population and restore public order.
On November 26, in Kinshasa city, the US embassy in DR Congo closed over a terror threat.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 27 November, in Boikene, an unidentified armed group abducted 2 civilians (no further details available).

column8: CNRD: National Council for Renewal and Democracy
column17: On 28 Nov 2018, the Nyatura Domi and the NDC Guidon attacked CNRD positions in the villages of Kiyeye and Katsiru in Rutshuru territory. One CNRD fighter, one Nyatura Domi fighter and three civilians killed (5 fatalities coded across 2 events).

column17: 01 December. Lash between UDPS and FCC supporters in Kasai after posters were ripped. Thirty-five people were injured. No arms mentioned.

column17: 01 December. FARDC forces clashed with Mayi Mayi Yakutumba and FNL rebels in Majaga. Twelve fighters were killed during two days of clashes (disaggregated to six fatalities per day).

column17: 01 December. FARDC forces launched operations to retake control of Muhangi from the Mayi Mayi Mazembe. They regained control of the town while operations were said to be ongoing as of December 2 in the nearby villages of Makoko, Mambungu and Mabambi.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 02 December. The FARDC clashed with Mayi Mayi Yakutumba and FNL groups in Majaga. Twelve fatalities occurred during two days of fighting (disaggregated as six per day).

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 02 December. FARDC forces launched operations to retake control of areas in Lubera from the Mayi Mayi Mazembe.Fighting was ongoing as of December 2 in Makoko, Mambungu and Mabambi.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 02 December. FARDC forces launched operations to retake control of areas in Lubera from the Mayi Mayi Mazembe.Fighting was ongoing as of December 2 in Makoko, Mambungu and Mabambi.

column17: 02 December. FARDC forces launched operations to retake control of areas in Lubera from the Mayi Mayi Mazembe.Fighting was ongoing as of December 2 in Makoko, Mambungu and Mabambi.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 04 December. A FARDC patrol was attacked by an unidentified group in Landjo, Djugu.

column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

06 December. The ADF attacked civilians in Mangolikene (one source indicated Mayangose) with machetes as they went to their fields. Twelve people were killed (some sources reported 13).
06 December. The ADF killed five people in Paida (other sources indicated it occurred in Rwangoma), including at least one woman and one child.
06 December. A convoy of UPC politicians was traveling between Kitchanga and Mweso when it was ambushed by Nyatura-Domi forces, in Bunande (no coordinates available). 17 people were injured.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column17: 06 December. FARDC were attacked by the ADF when they attempted to collect the bodies of civilians killed in Mangolikene (one source indicated Mayangose) earlier in the day. It is unclear if the attack occurred in the same village. The military was forced to retreat.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

The perpetrators demanded a ransom (Kidnappings for ransom in eastern DRC are sometimes carried out by former members of armed groups, with support of military officials who receive part of the profit).
09 December (on or before). Mayi Mayi Kihebe looted livestock from Mulama and Rurambira in Uvira.

The PPRD supporters sought to disrupt the rally. Police utilized live ammunition to disperse the clash. Eight people were injured, including four who sustained gun shot wounds. Lamuka coalition party offices were also vandalized.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column7: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 11 December. Lamuka coalition supporters and police clashed in Lubumbashi amidst Fayulu's arrival for a campaign rally. Police fired tear gas and water cannons at supporters who had gathered around the city, including at Fayulu's motorcade. Fayulu's supporters burned vehicles. Police said they dispersed the Lamuka supporters for burning vehicles, while Fayulu's speakers report the police initiated it to prevent the Lamuka rally. Civil society organizations report at least one death by shooting (possibly two) and 43 injuries , while the police reported 13 injuries and denied any fatalities. The UN HRC reported three fatalities and several injuries.

column17: 12 December. An armed group abducted a man from his farm in Rutoboko and killed him near by (approx coordinates based on Kivu security tracker map)

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column6: CMC-FNLD: Collective Movement for Change-Front for National Liberation and Democracy

On 14 Dec 2018, Rebels of the Republican Forces of Burundi (also known as the Popular Forces of Burundi, PFB) clashed with the Mai-Mai Kashumba who intervened following the PFB's killing of two people at Kasenya village in Uvira territory. One Mai-Mai Kashumba militant and two FPB fighters were killed.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column9: Former FPB: Popular Forces of Burundi
column17: On 14 Dec 2018, Rebels of the Republican Forces of Burundi (also known as the Popular Forces of Burundi, PFB) killed a man who had deserted their ranks and the woman with whom he had taken refuge with at Kasenya village in Uvira territory. The attackers also wounded a baby.
14 December. A Burundian was killed in the Muhungu area after he tried to defect from FOREBU to join the Mayi Mayi Gashumba.

On 14 December 2018, presumed ADF rebels set two ambushes between Kaskivi and Mukoko village (Beni, Nord-Kivu). The second was on motorcycle taxi drivers and their customers. The motorcycles were burnt and two civilians were reported missing.

column17: In December 2018 [coded to 15 December], CNRD militiamen have been attacked by a coalition of approximately 300 well-armed NDC-R and Nyatura John Love combatants. At least 18 civilians and 15 combatants were killed during the attack.

column17: On 15 December 2018, in Maibo (aka Kisiki), an unidentified armed group attacked civilians, injuring 2 .

column9: UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: 16 December. UDPS supporters gathered at the airport in Tshikapa for the arrival of presidential candidate Tshisekedi, when FCC supporters began throwing objects at the opposition members. The groups clashed, one person was killed by stones and another, believed to be a UDPS supporter, was beaten to death. Several others were injured. Police utilized tear gas to restore order.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 16 December 2018, in Mbau, an unidentified armed group attacked civilians, injuring 1 (no further details available).

Two people, including a police officer were abducted by the attackers. The police officer was later released, with serious injuries. A ransom has been demanded for the other abductee.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: 16 December. FARDC forces clashed with the FDLR at the base of the Mikeno volcano (located in the Virunga National park). Two soldiers were killed during the clashes which lasted two days (coded as one fatality per day).

column6: Batende Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Banunu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column16: AFP; UN HRC; MONUSCO; Radio Okapi
column17: 16 December. A group of 3,000 armed Batende attacked Yumbi city - particularly the neighborhoods of Noyi, Bolu, Likolo, and Ntsentseke. Local police members participated along the Batende (the head of the police had disarmed Banunu officers prior to the attack). Armed Banunu members retliated in some areas with support from a member of the naval forces. Civilians were shot, stabbed, mutilated, and burned to death; over 900 properties were damaged including homes, schools and churches. A MONUSCO investigation confirmed 170 fatalities, primarily from the Banunu community (the number may be higher due to uncounted bodies dumped into the river). The attack came after a communal dispute over the burial of the Banunu's customary chief on land belonging to Batende on 14/12. Local CSOs indicate that the group's political allegiances of the Batende with the FCC and Banunu with the Lamuka Coalition exacerbated the dispute.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: On 16 December 2018, in Mungoro (5 km from Mavivi), the ADF attacked civilians. FARDC and MONUSCO forces repelled the attack.
16 December. During the weekend, approximately 100 former employees of the Chisambo government protested in Bukavu over delayed payments.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 16 December 2018, presumed Mayi Mayi militiamen clashed with FARDC when they attempted to break into a warehouse in Beni city (Beni, Nord-Kivu). One militiaman was captured during the clash that lasted two hours.

column9: PPRD: Peoples Party for Reconstruction and Democracy
column17: 17 December. The AARC and PPRD (both members of the FCC) clashed in Ubundu, after the PPRD members prevented an AARC candidate from accessing his house. Five people were seriously injured in the clash

17 December. Raia Mutomboki-Ndarumanga attacked Bisangani (coordinates are approximate; based off of Kivu Security Tracker map). The perpetrators looted livestock and abducted locals (four people from Bisangani and Kibumba).
17 December. Raia Mutomboki-Ndarumanga attacked Kibumba. The group looted livestock and abducted a total of four people from Kibumba and Bisangani, which they also attacked.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 17 December 2018, in unspecified location [coded to Kinshasa], unidentified armed group abducted 1 civilian (no further details available).

14 - 21 December. A Mayi Mayi group has moved into Masumo, where they are taxing the local population.

column9: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: 17 December. The FARDC, with support from MONUSCO, responded to the ADF attack on Mangboko and repelled the attackers.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: 17 December. The FARDC and FDLR continued to clash near the Mikeno volcano in Virunga National Park. Two soldiers were killed during the clashes (recorded as one fatality per day).

column6: Batende Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) Naval Forces
column16: UN HRC; AFP; Radio Okapi; MONUSCO
column17: 17 December. Suspected Batende militia members attacked Nkolo 2, a Banunu community. Two naval officers attempted to repel the attackers, but one of the soldiers was killed and the other is missing. Much of the Nkolo 2 population had fled following the Yumbi city attack on 16/12. A MONUSCO investigation confirmed at least 10 fatalities in Nkolo 2. Homes, churches and schools were destroyed. Investigations found that the attacked on the Banunu were likely planned in advance.

column6: Batende Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Banunu Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo); Women (Democratic Republic of Congo); Men (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column16: Radio Okapi; AFP; UN HRC; MONUSCO
column17: 17 December. Following the attack on Yumbi city on 16/12, suspected Batende militia members attacked Bongende, Yumbi. The assailants mutilated the victims, removing limbs and sexual organs of men, women and children. Fetuses were cut out of pregnant women. At least one woman was raped and two children were reportedly abducted. A MONUSCO investigation confirmed 348 fatalities in Bongende, however, they suspected the actual number to be higher. Investigations found that the attacked on the Banunu were likely planned in advance and soldiers participated in the attacks on Bongende.

column6: Batende Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Banunu Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column16: Radio Okapi; MONUSCO; AFP; UN HRC
column17: 17 December. Following the communal attacks in Yumbi, suspected Batende militia members attacked Banunu members in Camp Nbanzi (no coordinates available; 70 km from Yumbi). At least seven people were killed.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column17: 19 December. The government in Kinshasa banned all campaign rallies and events in the city four days before the presidential election. Police forces also blocked Lamuka presidential candidate Martin Fayulu's convoy in Nsele to prevent him from entering Kinshasa city later on.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 19 December (on or before). Burundian refugees in Lusenda were prohibited from leaving the refugee camp as a security measure before the elections in DRC.

The police brought the journalist to the politician's house, where they beat him for several hours. He was later taken to a police station in Kinshasa.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 19 December. In response to Fayulu's prevention from entering Kinshasa, Lamuka members burned tires in the street and barricaded the road. Police responded with tear gas and shots were heard.

column6: Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 26 December. CENI announced the postponement of elections in Yumbi, Beni and Butembo until March 2019, citing insecurity and Ebola. The election schedule is set to remain the same for the rest of the country. Beni and Butembo were seen as strong-holds of the opposition parties.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 26 December. Following the postponement of elections in Butembo, demonstrators barricaded the roads and burned tires. Police forces dispersed the demonstrators.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 26 December. The FARDC captured the second in command of Raia Mutomboki- Hamakombo faction, Isaac Cirhabissa, and three other rebels in Katubiro (no coordinates available), a village in the Kalima area.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 27 December. An unidentified group looted Shanje (coordinates are approximate, based on Kivu Security map). They then abducted two men to carry the stolen property.

27 December (or after). Rioters, angry that CENI cited the Ebola outbreak as one of the reasons for postponing the election, caused property damage to an Ebola center in Mutwanga, Oicha. No further details available. [size=no report]

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 27 December. Demonstrations led by LUCHA continued in Beni against the postponement of elections in the region. The demonstrators burned tires and ransacked a Ebola facility, causing the patients to flee. The home of a police officer was also set on fire. Security forces fired to disperse the rioters. One demonstrator was killed, three police were injured, four LUCHA members were injured and 17 rioters were arrested.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 27 December. Angry over election delays in Beni, Butembo and Yumbi, demonstrators barricaded roads in Goma. Police utilized tear gas to disperse the demonstrators.

column6: Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

27 December (or after). Rioters, angry that CENI cited the Ebola outbreak as one of the reasons for postponing the election, caused property damage to an Ebola center in Bulongo, Oicha. No further details available. [size=no report]

27 December (or after). Rioters, angry that CENI cited the Ebola outbreak as one of the reasons for postponing the election, caused property damage to an Ebola center in Kisima, Beni. No further details available. [size=no report]

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 29 December 2018, in Boikene, unidentified armed group abducted 1 civilian (no further details available).

30 December. Voters in Kananga assaulted a CENI employee who wanted to take one of the voting machines out of a polling station. Police intervened to disperse the crowd, which led to the voters and police throwing objects at each other. Voting was suspended at the Sola Gratia school.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 30 December. Protests over problems with voting machines were ""violently dispersed"" in Inongo. No indication if they were dispersed by police or military forces.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column17: 30 December. Voters at the Lurhala school in Walungu became angry when a man in the polling center was urging others to vote for Shadary. A police opened fire to disperse the group, killing one man. The CENI president reported that a CENI technician was lynched by an angry mob because they thought he was tampering with a voting machine.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 30 December. After a police officer shot and killed a man, an angry mob in Walungu beat the officer to death. However, CENI stated the police officer was killed when voters suspected a CENI employee of tampering with voting machines.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 30 December 2018, at PK 25 road near Mbau, an unidentified armed group clashed with FARDC, killing 2 soldiers and injuring 7 (no further details available).

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019); Mayi Mayi Militia (Kifuafua); Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazembe); NDC: Nduma Defence of Congo; NDC-G: Nduma Defence of Congo (Guidon); APCLS-M: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo (Mapenzi); Nyatura-FDLR Coalition: Nyatura -Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda; Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura) Domi Faction
column17: 30 December. Voter intimidation during the voting for the presidential elections reported in various areas of Nord-Kivu. Security forces interfered with voting at some polling locations in Mulimbi and Butare (Rutshuru) and Mutongo (Walikale). Armed groups also interfered: the Mayi Mayi Kifuafua for Shadary in Walikale territory; NDC and Mayi Mayi Mazembe in Kasiki, Bunyatenge, Kinyatsi, and Mbwavinywa (Lubero); NDC-Guidon and APCLS Mapenzi for Shadary at polls in Mwendabandu ((Bukombo, Lwibo, Lushebere, Ngesha, Bugoye, Bushore, Bonde villages)) (Masisi territory). Meanwhile, Nyatura-FDLR coalition and Nyatura-Domi for Fayulu in polling sites in the Bwito region (Rutshuru).

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 30 December. Protests over problems with voting machines were ""violently dispersed"" in Inongo. Other sources indicate that voters ransacked a polling station. No indication if they were dispersed by police or military forces.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo); Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki)
column17: 30 December. Police and armed groups in Maniema prevented opposition supporters from going to polling stations during the voting for the presidential elections. Raia Mutomboki also interfered in Walowa Yu.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 30 December. Protests occurred in Bulungu, Kwilu over corruption allegations against a politician. A soldier guarding the politician shot and killed a man. [size=no report]

30 December. Clashes occurred between FCC supporters and opposition party supporters in Ditunda in Kasai (no coordinates available). The clash began as opposition election observers were prevented by CENI officials from entering polling stations. Seven people were seriously injured and voting was suspended in the town.
30 December. A CENI employee was assaulted by a group of voters after he allowed candidate Bitika Pascal to enter a polling station in Kindu. Police intervened to stop the assault.

column6: UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: 30 December. UDPS gunmen assaulted FCC supporters to prevent them from voting at some polling stations in Kasai Oriental.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 30 December. A grenade exploded at a polling station in Mulo, one person was injured.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 30 December. Armed groups reportedly interfered with voting at some polling locations in the Shabunda territory.
30 December. A CENI employee in Boma was attacked by a mob of voters when he went to replace a malfunctioning machine. The mob suspected him of bringing a fraudulent machine. Police intervened.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 31 December. An unidentified armed group killed two women in Kasenga and stole their livestock.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: CENCO: National Episcopal Conference of Congo
column17: 31 December (on or around). Independent election observers from CENCO were prohibited by police from observing ballot counting in polling stations in Lubumbashi.

column6: Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 31 December. The government cut internet and SMS access across the country. They also cut the radio signal of RFI and revoked the press credentials of one of the outlets journalist after the station reported on preliminary election results. The restrictions were implemented to prevent the spread of rumors as the presidential election tallies are completed.
31 December. The Nsabanga militia (a faction of Kamwina Nsapu) looted Kalulu village in Kasai Central (no coordinates available, in the Tshikula area).

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 31 December. An unknown group set fire to three voting machines which were located at a CENI employee's home in Katanda.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: NDC-R: Nduma Defence of Congo (Renewal); Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura-Kavumbi); Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura) Bohoza Faction
column17: 01 January - 28 March. The NDC-R, Nyatura Kibumba, and Nyatura Bohoza raped separately at least 57 women in the Bashali-Mokoto territory, leaving three killed. Two attacks occurred on 14/01. The remaining attacks were coded as one event per week over the mentioned period (12 events). Women were most frequently attacked by combatants while tending to their fields. A number of armed groups are vying for control of the territory.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 01 - 31 January. During the month of January, 44 people from the Kiwanja area were kidnapped, including 11 children. The abductions are carried out by armed groups and criminals who seek ransoms. Most of the abductions target women. Coded as one VAC event each week of January.
01 January (on or around). Nyatura forces established a base at Ngugo village (coordinates are appoximate based on OCHA map), in the Rutshuru territory.
02 January. Mayi Mayi Fimbo na Fimbo Bitonto ambushed a company convoy near Mulange village. One person was killed and others were injured, including a Chinese employee of the company.
04 January. Mayi Mayi Mwenyemali abducted two men near Bwesho (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security map). The perpetrators demanded a ransom.
05 January 2019. Mayi Mayi Fimbo na Fimbo harassed civilians and looted Kasebu, Tanganyika (coordinates are approximate based on location 65 km south of Kalemie).

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 05 January. An armed group, wearing hoods, broke into a radio station in Mbuji Mayi and destroyed equipment. Later in the night, an armed group opened fire on the building of the radio station. Despite it's proximity to a police station, security forces did not respond to the gunfire.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 05 January. During the night, two people were killed in their house in the Kabwela area of Kalemie by unknown perpetrators.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 01 May 2019. An FARDC patrol clashed with the ADF near Bovata, Oicha. According to local civil society, the military repelled the group into Virunga Forest. The FARDC recovered AK-47s and PKMs. Military sources reported that on 03/05 , an FARDC patrol found the bodies of two men who are suspected of being captured by the ADF during the attack on Bovata, and later killed.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 05 January. The police issued a ban on any public gathering of two people or more in Kananga. The ban comes in anticipation of the election results.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: 01 May 2019. The FARDC and FDLR clashed near Kakomero, Rutshuru (no coordinates available; in the Rugari area). Two soldiers were killed during the clashes.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column9: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-); Civilians (International)
column17: 01 May 2019. The FARDC carried out a sweep on the Vangu military camp in Lubumbashi. 'A large number' of arrests were made of soldiers, police, deserters, and West African nationals in connection to criminal attacks which have plagued the city.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 05 January. Police arbitrarily arrested 79 people in Goma, who were celebrating the rumored victory of Martin Fayulu.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 01 May 2019. After being ambushed by the FDLR earlier in the day, FARDC forces attacked the civilian population in Rugari. Six civilians, including three women, were killed in the retaliatory attack. The military denied the attacked but accused the local population of cooperating with the FDLR.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: 01 May 2019. The FARDC and FDLR clashed in the Shoko valley, located in the Tongo groupment of Rutshuru.

01 May 2019. An angry mob attacked illegal road barriers erected by police along the Kisangani-Banalia road and Kisangani-Opala road. The mob also destroyed 21 houses and offices of the traffic police. [size=no report]

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: On 6 January, at PK 20 road near Mbau, unidentified armed group clashed with FARDC, injuring 1.
Around 7 January 2019 (between 7 - 8 January), presumed ADF fighters killed 10 people in Nzuma-Mavivi (Beni, Nord-Kivu).

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: NDC-R: Nduma Defence of Congo (Renewal); Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura-Kavumbi); Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura) Bohoza Faction
column17: 01 January - 28 March. The NDC-R, Nyatura Kibumba, and Nyatura Bohoza raped separately at least 57 women in the Bashali-Mokoto territory, leaving three killed. Two attacks occurred on 14/01. The remaining attacks were coded as one event per week over the mentioned period (12 events). Women were most frequently attacked by combatants while tending to their fields. A number of armed groups are vying for control of the territory.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 07 January. During the night, a girl was tortured and raped in the Bankoko neighborhood of Bunia. She died the following day. Some locals attribute this crime to the release of militant prisoners at the end of December.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 07 January. The FARDC overtook the Nyatura camp in Ngugo (coordinates are appoximate based on OCHA map), in the Rutshuru territory. The militia fled into Virunga park.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 07 January (on or before). Additional police forces were deployed throughout Goma after the announcement of the presidential election winner was postponed.

column8: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: On 7 January, in Mavivi, ADF, killed 11 civilians, including 6 children and injuring 1. MONUSCO intervened. The ADF also abducted civilians during the attack.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 07 January. Two armed men abducted a Ugandan man from Munyaga, while he was tending to his field located in the DRC (Location coded as Nyamilima with precision of 3 as it is the DRC town closest to Munyaga).

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 01 - 31 January. During the month of January, 44 people from the Kiwanja area were kidnapped, including 11 children. The abductions are carried out by armed groups and criminals who seek ransoms. Most of the abductions target women. Coded as one VAC event each week of January.

09 January. The ADF attacked Mayi Safi and Kanake (coordinates for Kanake are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). Seven people were killed (coded as four fatalities in Mayi Safi and three in Kanake).

09 January. LRA forces abducted 11 civilians, including four children, 5 km west of Pangu, Bas Uele. The combatants also looted civilians traveling along the road in the same location. The adult abductees were later released, but the assailants did not release the children.

09 January. ADF attacked the villages of Kenake and Maisafi (no coordinates available), near Eringeti. Seven people were killed and nine other people were injured. The group also abducted civilians, 14 of which were released days later while others are still held by the group.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: 09-23 January (on or around). FARDC led two weeks of military operations against FDLR bases in Nord-Kivu, regaining key posts such as the FDLR base in Faringa, Bwito (Rutshuru). After Faringa was captured, fighting continued in Rubaya of Masisi as the FDLR fighters tried to retreat to Sud-Kivu. 10 fatalities during operations. Coded as two events per week, two in Faringa, two in Rubaya, with 10 fatalities spread across the events.
09-10 January. The Nsabanga militia (a faction of Kamwina Nsapu) looted Bukondo village in Kasai Central.
09-10 January. The Nsabanga militia (a faction of Kamwina Nsapu) looted Kamenga, Kasai Central
09-10 January. The Nsabanga militia (a faction of Kamwina Nsapu) looted Mulemba, Kasai Central.
09-10 January. The Nsabanga militia (a faction of Kamwina Nsapu) looted Kamuandu, Kasai Central.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: On 9 January, in Mayi Safi, ADF clashed with FARDC, killing 4 and injuring 4 soldiers. Additionally 8 civilians were killed, 11 injured and 21 were reported missing. Later reports indicate 12 out of 21 missing civilians were released.

column6: Luba Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Phende Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 10 January 2019. A group of Luba attacked a Phende group in the Kasai province.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: 01-31 January 2019. During the month of January, FRPI, who were in the midst of peace negotiations, looted at least three villages in the Aveba and Geti areas. The assailants raped a 15 year-old girl during one of the attacks. Coded as three events at random points in January - two looting and one violence against civilians.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 10 January. A militia group (unclear if they were armed) joined election celebrations in Tshikapa, but military forces thought they were going to attack and opened fire on the crowd, killing five people.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 10 January. Soldiers shot at civilians who were celebrating election results in Mutshima, Kamonia. One person was killed.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 10 January. Police opened fire to disperse a crowd celebrating the election results, injuring three people.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 10 January. Youth, angry over the declaration of Tshisekedi as the winner of the presidential election, barricaded several roads in Kikwit, destroyed local government buildings, and looted property. Police responded by opening fire on the group, killing three according to some sources. The police reported two civilian deaths and the death of a police officer's wife in their home. Other sources indicated as many as six fatalities.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 10 January. Demonstrators protested the election of Tshisekedi in Kisangani, by barricading roads and vandalizing the home of the local CENI representative. Arrests were made.

column7: Chokwe Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Luba Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 10 January (on or around). Tshokwe Lamuka supporters clashed with Luba FCC supporters in Kamonia. Two Luba were wounded by machetes.
10 January. Demonstrators angry over the election of Tshisekedi barricaded roads in Kabondo, a suburb of Kisangani.
10 January. Demonstrators angry over the election of Tshisekedi barricaded roads in Mangobo, a suburb of Kisangani.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 11 January. Soldiers forced 16 civilians to carry military belongings to Swima, Fizi. No indication if/when the civilians were released.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 11 January (on or before). A murdered body was discovered in the Nkadu neighborhood of Bukavu.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 11 January (on or before). An unidentified armed group killed three men in their fields in Butaro, Rutshuru (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map).

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 11 January. Unidentified armed men shot and killed an elderly man in Kikumba, Beni (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map).

11 January. LRA forces ambushed civilians 5 km south of Bambangana, Haut Uele. The assailants looted goods and held 36 civilians hostage (including six children), and released them at the end of the day.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 11 January. Police used tear gas to disperse a Lamuka rally held by Fayulu in Kinshasa.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 11 January. Demonstrators, including students, angry over the election results barricaded roads in Mbandaka. Police opened fire to disperse the demonstrators, wounding several.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 11 January. Police forces arbitrarily arrested 32 people, including 27 children, who were celebrating an election announcement in Lubumbashi.
11 January. Taxi drivers and other residents, opposed to the construction of an Ebola isolation center in Marabo, threw rocks at NGO health workers.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 12 January. An unidentified armed group abducted a man in Kimbulu, near the Biena bridge.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 12 January. An unidentified armed group abducted 10 people on their way to their fields near Kibende (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). The perpetrators demanded a $5,000 ransom.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 12 January. An unidentified armed group abducted two men from Kingarabe (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security map). The assailants demanded a ransom.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 12 January. The FARDC intercepted an attack on Nyakakoma, by Charles Kakule's Mayi Mayi forces. One attacker was killed and one civilian was injured.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 12 January. Protesters demonstrated against the election results in Buhene (no coordinates available) in Nyiragongo. The demonstrators clashed with police, who responded with live ammunition, killing a taxi driver who was passing through the demonstration and injuring another.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 12 January. Police used tear gas to disperse Lamuka protesters in Beni.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: NDC-R: Nduma Defence of Congo (Renewal); APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column17: 14 January. Either the NDC-Renove or the APCLS attacked an unspecified village in Masisi, accusing the residents of voting for the wrong candidates. At least 10 people were killed during this attack and a subsequent attack on 14/01. At least two women were raped during the attacks. The fatalities are split between the incidents.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 13 January. The FARDC attacked the Raia Mutomboki Mabala in Lwamba, Shabunda (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). Two militia members were captured.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: 09-23 January (on or around). FARDC led two weeks of military operations against FDLR bases in Nord-Kivu, regaining key posts such as the FDLR base in Faringa, Bwito (Rutshuru). After Faringa was captured, fighting continued in Rubaya of Masisi as the FDLR fighters tried to retreat to Sud-Kivu. 10 fatalities during operations. Coded as two events per week, two in Faringa, two in Rubaya, with 10 fatalities spread across the events.

column6: APCLS-M: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo (Mapenzi)
column17: 14 January. Mapenzi (aka Lola Hale) combatants abducted 10 men from Nyabiondo. They accused the abductees of supporting the APCLS.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 14 January. An unidentified armed group killed a man in Kausa, Masisi.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: NDC-R: Nduma Defence of Congo (Renewal); Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura-Kavumbi); Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura) Bohoza Faction
