Women were most frequently attacked by combatants while tending to their fields. A number of armed groups are vying for control of the territory.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 14 January. The military in Haut Uele reported killing five members of an armed group (they did not specify the group, but the LRA is active in the state).

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: NDC-R: Nduma Defence of Congo (Renewal); APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column17: 14 January. Either the NDC-Renove or the APCLS attacked an unspecified village in Masisi, accusing the residents of voting for the wrong candidates. At least 10 people were killed during this attack and a subsequent attack on 14/01. At least two women were raped during the attacks. The fatalities are split between the incidents.
15 January. The Raia Mutomboki Shukuru abducted three men from Kashewe, Kalehe. The assailants also looted live stock.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 15 January. Veranda Mutsanga members protested in Butembo, calling for the release of their leader and actual election results. Police and military forces dispersed the demonstration.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 15 January. The FARDC clashed with Nyatura Kigingi forces in Kaniro, Masisi.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Around 15 January 2019 (between 15 - 16 January), the chauffeur for the old vice-president of the provincial assembly was kidnapped by an unidentified armed group along the Beni-Butembo highway in Beni territory (Beni, Nord-Kivu).

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: 01-31 January 2019. During the month of January, FRPI, who were in the midst of peace negotiations, looted at least three villages in the Aveba and Geti areas. The assailants raped a 15 year-old girl during one of the attacks. Coded as three events at random points in January - two looting and one violence against civilians.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 01 - 31 January. During the month of January, 44 people from the Kiwanja area were kidnapped, including 11 children. The abductions are carried out by armed groups and criminals who seek ransoms. Most of the abductions target women. Coded as one VAC event each week of January.

column7: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction); Mayi Mayi Militia (Kijangala)
column17: 15 January. Residents of the Kabere area reported the movement of Burundi soldiers and Imbonerakure into the region with the assistance of the Mayi Mayi Kijangala.

column8: Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 15 January. 50 militia leaders associated with Kamwina Nsapu surrendered themselves to local authorities in Kananga. The ex-combatants stated that due to the outcome of the presidential elections they no longer needed to take up arms.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 15 January. An unidentified armed group attacked Terali (coordinates are approximate based on reported location 68 km south of Mahagi), looting the village. Soldiers from Kpandroma were deployed and repelled the group. Three perpetrators were arrested.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 15 January. FARDC forces attacked the base of an armed group operating in the Irumu territory. The base was located in the Songolo or Batalolo area. Following 30 minutes of clashes, the military captured the armed men.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: CNRD: National Council for Renewal and Democracy
column17: 16 January. The CNRD were forced out of Mokoto by other armed groups seeking control of the area.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 16 January. Supporters of a local female candidate protested against poll results - believing their candidate had actually won. Police intervened and arrested 45 protesters.

column7: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction); Mayi Mayi Militia (Kijangala)
column9: RED-TABARA: Resistance to the Rule of Law in Burundi; FNL: National Forces of Liberation; Mayi Mayi Militia (Kihebe)
column17: 16 January. Military forces from Burundi, along with Imbonerakure and Mayi Mayi Kijangala attacked Burundi rebels groups FOREBU, Red TABARA, and the FNL in Kabere, who were assisted by Mayi Mayi Kihebe. The fighting spread to Mubere and Mulenge. 17 rebels were killed (fatalities spread over three locations).

column7: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction); Mayi Mayi Militia (Kijangala)
column9: RED-TABARA: Resistance to the Rule of Law in Burundi; FNL: National Forces of Liberation; Mayi Mayi Militia (Kihebe)
column17: 16 January. Military forces from Burundi, along with Imbonerakure and Mayi Mayi Kijangala attacked Burundi rebels groups FOREBU, Red TABARA, and the FNL in Kabere, who were assisted by Mayi Mayi Kihebe. The fighting spread to Mubere and Mulenge. 17 rebels were killed (fatalities spread over three locations).

column9: RED-TABARA: Resistance to the Rule of Law in Burundi; FNL: National Forces of Liberation; Mayi Mayi Militia (Kihebe)

The fighting spread to Mubere and Mulenge. 17 rebels were killed (fatalities spread over three locations).

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 17 January. An unidentified armed group looted homes and killed a woman in Buloli, Kabare (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map).

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 17 January. An unidentified armed group ambushed a microbus near Mujangala, Walungu (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). The perpetrators killed one man and injured another. The assailants also stole the passengers' belongings.
17 January. The LRA robbed a woman near Nabakpa, Haut Uele.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 17 January, in Semuliki (no coordinates available, along the Mbau-Kamango road), an unidentified armed group attacked civilians (no further details available).

column6: Walendu Pitsi Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 17 January (on or around). 20 villages in the Ngakpa and Uketa (no coordinates available) areas of Djugu were looted and burned by a neighboring group from the Walendu Pitsi community. Over 1,500 homes in the area were destroyed.

column6: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 18 January 2019. A Batwa militia, along with Mayi Mayi Yakutumba, raided the Majengo mine, in the northeastern area of the Bendera territory.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: CNRD: National Council for Renewal and Democracy
column17: 18 January. The FARDC clashed with the CNRD in Buguri (coordinates are approximate based on OCHA map), in Masisi. Five soldiers and two rebels were killed.

column6: CNRD: National Council for Renewal and Democracy
column17: On 18 January, in Kivuye, around 4000 CNRD members including 400 combatants left the group's stronghold and moved south towards South Kivu Province. The movement has been caused by growing number of attacks directed at the group.

column7: LUCHA: Fight for Change; FDR: Forces of Renewal; ECCHA: Citizen Engagement for Change
column17: 18 January. Members of LUCHA, FDR, and ECCHA protested in front of the AU's office in Kinshasa against the organization's call for an electoral recount.
18 January (on or around). CACH coalition supporters demonstrated in Bukavu, against the AU's call for an electoral recount. The group burned tires.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: 18 January (on or before). FDLR forces in Masisi, Nord Kivu moved out of the territory and into Sud Kivu. The movement comes as Rwandan rebel General Kyumba has created a coalition, seeking to carry out attacks on Rwanda from Sud Kivu, according to military sources.

column9: Unidentified Communal Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 19 January. LRA forces ambushed and looted 10 motorist along the road 10 km north of Kapili, Haut Uele. The group also abducted the Mbiangu chief, who they released the following day.
19 January. The NDC-Renove clashed with Nzayi's Nyatura faction in the Muzimo area of Mokoto, as both groups seek control of the area. Three Nyatura fighters and one NDC fighter were killed.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 19 January. Police fired tear gas to disperse crowds that gathered in Lubumbashi to welcome the return of Jean Muyambo, president of SCODE following his four year imprisonment in Kinshasa.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: 09-23 January (on or around). FARDC led two weeks of military operations against FDLR bases in Nord-Kivu, regaining key posts such as the FDLR base in Faringa, Bwito (Rutshuru). After Faringa was captured, fighting continued in Rubaya of Masisi as the FDLR fighters tried to retreat to Sud-Kivu. 10 fatalities during operations. Coded as two events per week, two in Faringa, two in Rubaya, with 10 fatalities spread across the events.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 20 January. Unidentified armed men killed two men and robbed a home in Kitchanga.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 20 January. An unidentified armed group attacked a minibus near Kayna, Lubero (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map), abducting five passengers and robbing them. They demanded a ransom.

20 January. Raia Mutomboki Shabani combatants attacked a group of Nyatura Nduhuye in the mining area of Kimoto, Kalehe (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). Three Nduhuye fighters and one Shabani combatant were killed.
20 January. NDC-Renove forces clashed with Nyatura-Nzayi in Kinyana, Masisi (no coordinates available). Five Nzayi combatants, one NDC-R fighter, and four civilians were killed.

column6: RED-TABARA: Resistance to the Rule of Law in Burundi
column17: 20 January. Red TABARA forces attacked military forces of Burundi and their allies, Mayi Mayi Kijangala, in Mulenge, Uvira. Eighteen died during the clash.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: 01-31 January 2019. During the month of January, FRPI, who were in the midst of peace negotiations, looted at least three villages in the Aveba and Geti areas. The assailants raped a 15 year-old girl during one of the attacks. Coded as three events at random points in January - two looting and one violence against civilians.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 20 January. An unidentified armed group shot and wounded a motorcyclist near Kulugbangu, Haut Uele. The group may have links to LRA as the event was reported by source tracking LRA activity.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) Eco-Guards
column17: 20 January (on or around). The FARDC and Eco Guards clashed with the Kakule militia, securing the release of 39 hostages being held by the group.
20 January. Clashes between the NDC-Renove and Nyatura-Nzayi continued in Munongo Kakonse (no coordinates available, in the Mokoto district). Six people were killed including two civilians.

20 January. The LRA ambushed three people on bikes along the Nambia-Bagandi road in Mabadabada village (no coordinates available, located in the Niangara territory). The perpetrators seriously injured one and looted their belongings.

column6: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column8: RED-TABARA: Resistance to the Rule of Law in Burundi
column9: FNL: National Forces of Liberation; Mayi Mayi Militia (Kihebe)
column17: 20 January. Imbonerakure attacked Red TABARA, FNL and Mayi Mayi Kihebe in Kihinga. The Imbonerakure forced the other armed groups out of the area. Five fatalities were reported in clashes in Kihinga and Nabahuri (coded as three fatalities in Kihinga and two in Nabahuri).

column6: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column8: RED-TABARA: Resistance to the Rule of Law in Burundi
column9: FNL: National Forces of Liberation; Mayi Mayi Militia (Kihebe)
column17: 20 January. Imbonerakure attacked Red TABARA, FNL and Mayi Mayi Kihebe in Nabahuri (no coordinates available; located in the Mulenge region). The Imbonerakure took control of the area. Five fatalities were reported in clashes in Kihinga and Nabahuri (coded as three fatalities in Kihinga and two in Nabahuri).

On 21 Jan 2019, the NDC Guidon attacked a Nyatura Nzayi position in Munongo village of Masisi territory. NDC Guidon militants chased Nyatura Nzayi fighters from their position. A man drowned during their escape.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 21 January. An unidentified group abducted two men from the Benengule neighborhood of Beni. The assailants tortured one of the abductees before releasing him. The man died of his injuries.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 21 January. Two unidentified armed men killed an elderly woman in the Rukangaga area of Kiliba, Uvira.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: NDC-R: Nduma Defence of Congo (Renewal); Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura-Kavumbi); Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura) Bohoza Faction
column17: 01 January - 28 March. The NDC-R, Nyatura Kibumba, and Nyatura Bohoza raped separately at least 57 women in the Bashali-Mokoto territory, leaving three killed. Two attacks occurred on 14/01. The remaining attacks were coded as one event per week over the mentioned period (12 events). Women were most frequently attacked by combatants while tending to their fields. A number of armed groups are vying for control of the territory.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 21 January. An armed group (suspected to be the same that carried out attacks in Rutobogo earlier on the same day), attacked Kimoka during the night. The perpetrators raped two women, killed another, and wounded three men.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: On 21 January, in Mapobu, the  ADF attacked and killed 25 FARDC soldiers and injured 22 other. Additionally 5 soldiers were reported missing. The UN Group of Experts collected evidence that corroborated this information. During the same period, several sources witnessed a high number of injured ADF combatants brought back to ADF camps, indicating their involvement in attacks and clashes. FARDC seized a type 80 general purpose machine gun from an ADF combatant.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 21 January. Police dispersed Lamuka supporters who gathered at the MLC headquarters in Kinshasa to listen to Martin Fayulu.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: 09-23 January (on or around). FARDC led two weeks of military operations against FDLR bases in Nord-Kivu, regaining key posts such as the FDLR base in Faringa, Bwito (Rutshuru). After Faringa was captured, fighting continued in Rubaya of Masisi as the FDLR fighters tried to retreat to Sud-Kivu. 10 fatalities during operations. Coded as two events per week, two in Faringa, two in Rubaya, with 10 fatalities spread across the events.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 21-22 January. Five civilians died during clashes in and around Luke between the FARDC and Nyatura Kasongo. Fatalities spread across two events.
21 January. The LRA barricaded the Dungu-Doruma road at Kana village. They then abducted 15 people and looted property, food, and money.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Aid Workers (Democratic Republic of Congo); Women (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 21 January. An armed group shot at an Oxfam vehicle in Rutobogo (coordinates are approximate, based on location 2 km west of Sake) and raped two women. The driver escaped. The armed group then ambushed a motorbike, killing two riders, while one managed to escape. Locals indicated that this group is also responsible for abductions in the area but provided no further details.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 22 Jan 2019, a policeman shot and killed a woman in Butare village of Masisi territory.
22 January. Mayi Mayi Buhirwa abducted a man from Narunanga, Uvira. The assailants demanded a $2,000 ransom.

column8: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column17: 22 January. The Nyatura Bohoza faction clashed with the APCLS in Nyabyara and Luala (no coordinates available), near Kahira in Masisi. Four civilians and seven fighters were killed during the clashes.

column6: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column8: RED-TABARA: Resistance to the Rule of Law in Burundi
column9: FNL: National Forces of Liberation; Mayi Mayi Militia (Kihebe)
column17: 22 January. Imbonerakure clashed with Red TABARA, FNL and Mayi Mayi Kihebe in Kifuni (no coordinates available), in the Kigoma area. The Imbonerakure pushed the armed groups into the Kitavuka Mbegere forest. Movements of Burundi military forces and Imbonerakure were reported across the border into the Kigoma area of DRC the same day.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 01 - 31 January. During the month of January, 44 people from the Kiwanja area were kidnapped, including 11 children. The abductions are carried out by armed groups and criminals who seek ransoms. Most of the abductions target women. Coded as one VAC event each week of January.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 22 January 2019. The Mayi Mayi Chuyi ambushed an FARDC convoy along the road from Kabambare to Pene-Mende (35 km south of Kilembwe). One militia member was killed and three soldiers were injured.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 22 January. The FARDC clashed with an armed group in Largu. The military reported three soldiers and five rebel fatalities. However, civil society has reported four military fatalities. Civil society reported the group looted arms from a military depot in town but the FARDC denied the report.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 22 January. The FARDC clashed with the Simba militia in Dembele (coordinates are approximate based on reports that the village is 15-17 km from Nia Nia, along the Kisangani road). The groups leaders, Manu and Abley, were killed along with five other members of the militia.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 22 January. Moise Tshiombe's militia crossed paths with the FARDC in Demba, as the armed group was traveling to Kananga to disarm. The soldiers attempted to disarm the militia on the spot, sparking a clash between the groups. One soldier was killed. Much of the local population fled, fearing retaliation by the military.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 21-22 January. Five civilians died during clashes in and around Luke between the FARDC and Nyatura Kasongo. Fatalities spread across two events.
22 January. Kakule's militia abducted 39 fishermen (other sources indicated 20) on Lake Edward.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 23 January. Three armed men tortured a woman in Rutare, Kalehe (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker). The woman died of her injuries.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 23 January. An unidentified armed group raided home and abducted a man in Mbuhi-Pilote.

23 January. The Raia Mutomboki Mungoro clashed with the Raia Mutomboki Ngandu after the Ngandu group looted a cow and goats from Nguku, Walikale (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). The Mungoro combatants recovered the stolen livestock.

column6: UPLC: Union of Patriots for the Liberation of Congo
column8: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 23 January. The UPLC abducted three members of MONUSCO in Kisalala. Shortly after the abduction, the FARDC freed the abductees.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 23 January. The military arrested Kamate Mungumwa and Muhindo Mbiriki, two leaders of the Mayi Mayi Mazembe in Kirumba. The leaders were unarmed at the time of arrest.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) Prison Guards
column17: 23 January. Prisoners in the Mbuji Mayi escaped through a tunnel. Guards opened fire on the inmates to prevent their escape. Some sources report five fatalities, while others indicate nine, including a prison guard.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 23 January, in Kididiwe, unidentified armed group attacked civilians, injuring 1. 1 civilian was reported missing.
23 January. Charles Kakule's militia abducted 30 fishermen on Lake Edward. Some of the abductees managed to escape, while the others were released following ransom payments.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Mwenga Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 23 January. An armed group attacked the Ruvungi market in Burhini, killing five and seriously injuring two others. The perpetrators targeted gold buyers. Other sources indicated that the attacked occurred in the Kakwende village in Mwenga, and resulted in the death of five assailants, one soldier, and one civilian. This source also noted that the civilian population defended itself against the attackers.

column8: RED-TABARA: Resistance to the Rule of Law in Burundi
column17: 24 January. Red TABARA combatants clashed with Mayi Mayi Kihebe in Kishagala, Uvira (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map) at a bar. One Kihebe combatant and one civilian were killed, while one other civilian was wounded.
24 January. The ADF ambushed an Okapi Logistics, NGO convoy near Kisiki. The assailants killed three and injured three during the robbery.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 24 January (on or before). The body of a murdered two-year old child was found in the Cikonyi neighborhood of Bukavu.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: On 24 January, in Mayimoya, an unidentified armed group clashed with FARDC, injuring 1 soldier. Additionally 3 civilians were killed and 3 injured.

24 January (on or before). ADF forces ambushed drivers on RN 4, in Kisiki-Mayimoya. Three people were killed, two were injured. Three Okapi vehicles were also intercepted but the drivers were not harmed.

column6: Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column7: UPDS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: 24 January. Felix Tshisekedi was inaugurated as president of the DRC.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 24 January. A Mayi Mayi group attacked soldiers based outside of Uvira city. Three soldiers were killed.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 26 January, in Malolu, unidentified armed group attacked civilians, injuring 1.
24 January. NDC-Renove forces clashed with the Nyatura Nzayi in Nyabura (no coordinates available; located in the Bahali-Mokoto district).

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 25 January. An unidentified armed group killed a man in Kitalaga, Kalehe (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map).

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 25 January. An unidentified armed group abducted a man from Muhani (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). The assailants demanded a $700 ransom.
25 January. Nyatura Niyonzimana abducted one man from Karambi and looted his home.

column6: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Bantu Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 25 January. During the night, a group of Batwa men from Ndubie looted Kiwete (no coordinates available), a Bantu village in Pweto. Residents of Kiwete and surrounding villages fled the area.

column6: Luba Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 25 January 2019. A Luba group attempted to attack the home of a national assembly member in Tshikapa. The police intervened and repelled the attackers.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 25 January. FARDC forces clashed with a coalition of Mayi Mayi militias in the Bavira chiefdom in the Kalungwe area. The military repelled the militias and recovered weapons.

column6: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column17: 25-26 January. Two-day clashes between APCLS and NDC-Renove in Shimbisha (no coordinates available; near Lukweti). Three NDC-Renove fighters, one APCLS fighter, and one civilian were killed (fatalities spread across two events).

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 25 January. The FARDC clashed with Mayi Mayi Rene in Muheta, Uvira forcing the armed group to flee and capturing territory.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 25 January. After forcing the Mayi Mayi Rene out of Muheta, the soldiers looted civilian property.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: On 26 January, at PK 26 road near Mbau, an unidentified armed group clashed with FARDC, killing 2 and injuring 14 soldiers .

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 26 January. Approximately 600 Kamwina Nsapu militia members arrived in Kananga, for voluntary disarmament in exchange for economic support.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 26 January (on or before). As the Kamwina Nsapu has begun disarming, members of the militia sought to disarm the police force in Nganza. The police fired into the air to repel the militia members.

column6: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column17: 25-26 January. Two-day clashes between APCLS and NDC-Renove in Shimbisha (no coordinates available; near Lukweti). Three NDC-Renove fighters, one APCLS fighter, and one civilian were killed (fatalities spread across two events).

column6: Banunu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Batende Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 26 January (on or before). More than 50 mass graves were discovered in the Yumbi area. The graves are from the clashes that occurred between the Banunu and Batende in mid-December 2018.
26 January. Mayi Mayi raped three women in Kwebo (no coordinates available; located in the Masisi territory).

26 January. Raia Mutomboki Kokodikoko and Raia Mutomboki Ngandu looted Tachinid, Shabunda (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). The assailants killed a man during the attack.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Aid Workers (Democratic Republic of Congo); ICRC: International Committee of the Red Cross and Red Crescent
column17: 27 January. An unidentified armed group abducted six people in Mubambiro, including two ICRC employees. The perpetrators also killed an infant, while they abducted the mother.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 27 January 2019. 46 Mayi Mayi Malaika combatants, including five children, and 10 other dependents voluntarily surrendered to the FARDC in Samba, Maniema.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 27 January. Students from the University of Lubumbashi demonstrated over water, electricity, and fees. The demonstrators barricaded roads, blocked access to the university, and burned tires and vehicles. Police forces opened fire on the demonstrators, killing three. A police officer also died after being hit by a police car.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 27 January. An armed group, who spoke Lingala and an unrecognized language, abducted a man 10 km west of Ngilima, Haut Uele. The abductee was released a few hours later. The group may have links to LRA as the event was reported by source tracking LRA activity.

column6: RED-TABARA: Resistance to the Rule of Law in Burundi
column7: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column17: 27 January. Following clashes between the Imbonerakure and Red TABARA, one of the armed groups looted the civilian population in Murambi (no coordinates available), near Kiryama (coordinates are approximate based on WFP map). Much of the local population fled into the forest.

column6: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column8: RED-TABARA: Resistance to the Rule of Law in Burundi
column17: 27 January. Imbonerakure clashed with Red TABARA in Murambi, near Kiryama (coordinates are approximate based on WFP map). Eight fatalities were reported and several civilians were injured. Red TABARA forces fled towards Kitoga.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 27 January 2019, unidentified armed men kidnapped 7 people, including 1 INGO national staff member, in an ambush on the road near Goma (Goma, Nord-Kivu). The aid worker was released hours later after the payment of a ransom.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: NDC-R: Nduma Defence of Congo (Renewal); Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura-Kavumbi); Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura) Bohoza Faction
column17: 01 January - 28 March. The NDC-R, Nyatura Kibumba, and Nyatura Bohoza raped separately at least 57 women in the Bashali-Mokoto territory, leaving three killed. Two attacks occurred on 14/01. The remaining attacks were coded as one event per week over the mentioned period (12 events). Women were most frequently attacked by combatants while tending to their fields. A number of armed groups are vying for control of the territory.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 28 January - 02 April: The FARDC launched operations against the Mayi Mayi Simba in the Babila Babombi and Bombo communes of Mambasa territory. 38 Mayi Mayi Simba were killed during the period. 12 are coded in Mapendano on 01/03. The remaining 26 fatalities are spread between 8 events during the time period (one battle per week).

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 28 January. Lokondo Luakatebua, Mubiayi Dewayi, and Mwamba Musolo- three high ranking leaders of the Kamwina Nsapu militia, along with 60 other members, surrendered in Luebo. This comes as much of the Kamwina Nsapu Militia has turned in their arms following the election of Tshisekedi.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 28 January. 43 members of the Mbawu Nkanka militia voluntarily disarmed in Tshikala.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 28 January. Students of the Institute of Technical Applications in Kinshasa protested over the increase of fees. Police responded and dispersed the demonstrators.

28 January. LRA combatants looted two travelers 11 km northeast of Bilikwa, Haut-Uele. They also looted another traveler 6 km northeast of Bilikwa. The assailants held the men hostage for a few hours before releasing them.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 28 January, at PK 19 road near Mbau, an unidentified armed group attacked civilians, killing 1.

28 January. Lubumbashi University students continued their demonstrations over access to water and electricity on campus, as well as university fees. They barricaded roads, blocked access to the university, and burned tires.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 28 January. An unidentified armed group robbed an ambulance and abducted the driver from the Lubero General Hospital, near Itolero (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker Map). The assailants demanded a $5,000 ransom.
28 January. Students of the Institute of Superior Pedagogy (ISP) in Bukavu demonstrated against school and syllabus fees. The students burned tires and barricaded roads.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 28 January. An unidentified armed group attacked a FARDC vehicle, near Kacungwe, Fizi (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). The soldiers pursued the perpetrators. One soldier was injured.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 29 January. An unidentified group abducted seven people from Kalengera. Three escaped, while the perpetrators are demanding a ransom for the others.
29 January. NDC-Renove fighters clashed with Nyatura Nzayi in Lwama, in Bashali. Four Nzayi members, three NDC-R members and three civilians were killed during the clashes.

column8: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column17: 29 January. The APCLS clashed with Bohoza's Nyatura fighters in Mipfungulu and Kise (no coordinates available for either location) in the Masisi territory. Four Bohoza fighters and two APCLS fighters were killed during the clashes.
29 January. University students in Lubumbashi continued their demonstrations, and barricaded access to the University of Lubumbashi.
29 January. Angry residents in Mubambiro burned military barracks to protest harassment by soldiers and insecurity.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 29 January. An unidentified armed group looted Loa Numbi, Kalehe. The assailants forced a man, a woman and three boys to carry the stolen property. No indication if they were released after.
30 January. In conjunction with their three day strike, TRANSCO employees in Kinshasa protested for their over due salaries and called for the resignation of the general manager of the company.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 30 January. A military site in Kahira was attacked by a Nyatura group.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 30 January (on or around). The FARDC clashed with LRA forces in Dungu, killing four rebels. One soldier was also killed during the clashes, but it is unclear if he was killed in Niangara or Dungu - where clashes also occurred - (the soldier's fatality was included in the Dungu fatalities).

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 30 January (on or around). The FARDC clashed with LRA forces in Niangara, killing five rebels. One soldier was also killed during the clashes, but it is unclear if he was killed in Niangara or Dungu - where clashes also occurred - (the soldier's fatality was included in the Dungu fatalities).

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 30 January. Ebuela wa Seba, leader of the Mtetezi militia, and 300 members of the armed group surrendered in Mikenge. The group cited the change of the ruling party as the reason for their voluntary disarmament.

column6: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 30 January. The FARDC clashed with APCLS forces in Kalihe and Lwanguba (no coordinates available; both villages are located in Masisi).
30 January. LRA combatants ambushed five civilians 7 km south of Limai. The attackers looted goods from the civilians and abducted three men.

column6: Chokwe Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Luba Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 30 January (on or around). Chokwe members attacked and injured a Luba man in the Kamonia territory. The attack was related to post-election communal tensions.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 31 January. An unidentified armed group killed a merchant in Kindu.
31 January. SONAS employees protested in Kinshasa over their outstanding salaries.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: UPLC: Union of Patriots for the Liberation of Congo
column17: 31 January. The FARDC attacked UPLC bases in Pabuka and Kalingathi. Approximately 20 rebels and two soldiers were killed in the operation (coded as 11 fatalities per location). Weapons were also seized.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: UPLC: Union of Patriots for the Liberation of Congo
column17: 31 January. The FARDC attacked UPLC bases in Pabuka and Kalingathi (no coordinates available; located south-east of Beni town). Approximately 20 rebels and two soldiers were killed in the operation (coded as 11 fatalities per location). Weapons were also seized.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 31 January. An unidentified armed group attempted to steal livestock near the Kinanira neighborhood of Sange. The FARDC repelled the attackers.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 31 January. After repelling an armed group from the area near the Kinanira neighborhood in Sange, the FARDC looted the local community.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column17: 31 January. The FARDC attacked an APCLS site in Buabo, Masisi (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). The APCLS repelled the military forces back to Masisi center. A child was injured during the clashes.
31 January. Mayi Mayi Rene forces abducted a woman from Nakiliba, Uvira (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). The perpetrators demanded a ransom.
31 January. Mayi Mayi Rene forces abducted a man from Kigongo, Uvira. The assailants demanded a ransom.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 31 January. An unidentified armed group killed a man in Orac, Uvira (no coordinates available).

31 January. The Nyatura FDP (Niyonzimana Faction) abducted and tortured six men from their fields near Burambo, Rutshuru (coordinates are approximate based on OCHA map). The victims were targeted after they failed to pay a fee to the militia. One of the men died from his injuries.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 28 January- 03 February. During the week, a 14 year-old girl was killed in Kiliba, Uvira by unidentified perpetrators.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 01 January. Residents of Kindu demonstrated against increased insecurity in the city, following the murder of a merchant the day prior. The demonstrators suspect police forces are behind the insecurity and attacked the Kindu police station. Police forces responded with tear gas and live ammunition. Two students were shot, according to Radio Okapi they were killed while Actualite reported they were injured. The demonstrators also attacked a radio station, where a police officer was hiding. Military forces were deployed to restore order.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 28 January- 03 February. During the week, three soldiers were killed in the Kakombe area of Uvira by unidentified assailants.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 28 January- 03 February. During the week, a soldier shot a woman in Mutarule, Uvira. Unclear if she was killed or wounded.
First half of February. The NDC-Renove imposed taxes and subjected civilians to forced labor in the towns of Luibo and Lukweti, Masisi - which the group occupies.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column9: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 28 January- 03 February. During the week, the FARDC carried out operations against LRA and other armed groups in the Dungu territory. Eight camps were destroyed in Dungu and Niangara during the operations.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column9: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 28 January- 03 February. During the week, the FARDC carried out operations against LRA and other armed groups in the Niangara territory. Eight camps were destroyed in Dungu and Niangara during the operations.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 01 February. An unidentified armed group stabbed a soldier in Musienene, Lubero (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). The assailants stole the soldier's weapon.
01 February. Raia Mutomboki Blaise combatants abducted three men and one woman from Mihanda, Kabare (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map).

column6: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column17: 01 February. Throughout the night, the APCLS clashed with Guidon's NDC-Renove in Bwenderu and Butsindo (no coordinates available for the villages, located in the Bashali-Mokoto groupment). Two APCLS and three NDC-Renove fighters were killed.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 02 - 03 February. An armed group abducted 14 farmers in Kashwa, Rutshuru, including 12 women. FARDC forces responded to the attack and exchanged fire with the assailants as they fled (coded in separate event).

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 02 - 03 February. FARDC forces responded to an attack by an armed group on farmers in Kashwa, Rutshuru, and exchanged fire with the assailants as they fled (coded in separate event). The gunmen had abducted 14 farmers (coded in separate event).

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 02 February. During the night, the FARDC clashed with an armed group which attacked Torges (no coordinates available, located 25 km from Blukwa, in the Bahema chieftaincy of Djugu). At least, six assailants and two soldiers were killed during the clashes.
02 February. Two journalists covering a Lamuka rally were assaulted and injured by Lamuka supporters.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 2 February, in Kasinga, an unidentified armed group attacked civilians (no further details available).

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 02 February. A journalist was assaulted by unidentified assailants in Lubumbashi. According to local members of the press, four journalist have 'recently' faced violence in the city.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 02 February. An armed group attacked Torges (no coordinates available, 25 km from Blukwa). The assailants looted the village, abducted four civilians and killed two others.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 01-28 February. 58 women and one child experienced conflict-related sexual violence in the DRC during the month of February. Coded as one attack per week.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 02 February. The ADF attacked the FARDC in the Boikene neighborhood of Beni. The FARDC repelled the attack. One soldier was killed.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 02 February. The FARDC attacked Mayi Mayi Mazembe in Kanyatsi, Lubero. Two soldiers and one militia member were killed during the clashes.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 02 February. Following clashes against the Mayi Mayi Mazembe, the FARDC looted civilian property in Kanyatsi, Lubero. The soldiers also raped a girl.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 02 February. An unidentified armed group abducted seven civilians on their way to their fields near Kasha, Rutshuru (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). The assailants demanded a ransom.

column6: UPLC: Union of Patriots for the Liberation of Congo
column17: 02 February. UPLC combatants opened fire on a home in Kitokolu, Beni (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). Two men were killed and one was injured.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 03 February (on or before). An armed group ambushed and robbed a bus traveling from Bukavu to Uvira near Rutemba, Sud Kivu. Nine civilians were injured during the attack.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 03 February. Following the murder of a civilian by a soldier in Yamokolo, the victims family brought the body to the territorial administrative office. Upon learning of the incident, Basoko residents gathered to protest the killing. Military forces opened fire to disperse the demonstrators, but ran out of ammunition. At which point, the mob attacked a soldier and burned him alive. The group also ransacked the police station and freed nine detainees.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 03 February. A soldier shot and killed a civilian in Yamokolo, Basoko.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-) Prison Guards
column9: Prisoners (Democratic Republic of Congo); Women (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 03 February. A female prisoner was whipped 100 times after refusing advances from the prison director. The prisoner was transferred to a hospital for medical treatment.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 03 February (on or before). An unidentified armed group killed a soldier in Rwangoma, Beni. The body was discovered in a bush.
03 February. Members of the Mayi Mayi Charles clashed amongst themselves near Kamuhororo, Rutshuru. Eight members were killed, including Charles Bokande, the leader of the group.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: NDC-R: Nduma Defence of Congo (Renewal); Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura-Kavumbi); Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura) Bohoza Faction
column17: 01 January - 28 March. The NDC-R, Nyatura Kibumba, and Nyatura Bohoza raped separately at least 57 women in the Bashali-Mokoto territory, leaving three killed. Two attacks occurred on 14/01. The remaining attacks were coded as one event per week over the mentioned period (12 events). Women were most frequently attacked by combatants while tending to their fields. A number of armed groups are vying for control of the territory.

column6: UPLC: Union of Patriots for the Liberation of Congo
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-) Prison Guards
column17: 04 February. The UPLC attacked a prison in Mabalako, releasing two members who had been captured during clashes on 31/01.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 28 January - 02 April: The FARDC launched operations against the Mayi Mayi Simba in the Babila Babombi and Bombo communes of Mambasa territory. 38 Mayi Mayi Simba were killed during the period. 12 are coded in Mapendano on 01/03. The remaining 26 fatalities are spread between 8 events during the time period (one battle per week).

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 04 February. Residents of the Keshero neighborhood of Goma caught a robber and police intervened to prevent the mob from attacking the robber. One police officer opened fire on the crowd of locals trying to disperse the mob, killing a teenage girl and injuring two male youths.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: On 4 February, in Mapobu (aka Kisiki), an unidentified armed group clashed with FARDC, killing 6 and injuring 2 soldiers (no further details available).
04 February. Firefighters protested in Kinshasa over the government's failure to pay their salaries for 38 months.

04 February. In conjunction with their strike over salary delays, employees of SCPT barricaded the entrance to the port with shipping containers. The employees also gathered at the entrance to the port, where they are waiting for the company to pay their salaries.

04 February. The NDC-Renove clashed with Nyatura-Nzayi in Munongo and Kakonse (no coordinates available), as the Nyatura-Nzayi are trying to take control of Lwama (coordinates are approximate based on OCHA map) from the NDC-Renove. Four Nyatura combatants, two NDC-Renove fighters and two civilians were killed during the clashed.

column7: Labour Group (Democratic Republic of Congo); Journalists (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 04 February. Members of the RTNC protested in front of the African Union headquarters in Kinshasa, demanding contract renegotiations and the resignation of Ernest Kabila, the director of the public media company.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 04 February. An unidentified armed group abducted a man in Kiriva, Lubero (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). The assailants killed the abductee.
04 February. Mayi Mayi Rushaba assaulted a man and abducted his wife in Rugenge, Uvira. The perpetrators also looted livestock. A $1,000 ransom was demanded.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 05 February (on or before). A soldier was attacked with machetes by an unidentified group in Rwangoma.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 05 February. Residents of Goma demonstrated after a police officer killed a teenager the prior night. The demonstrators set fire to the police station in Keshero, where the incident had occurred.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: RED-TABARA: Resistance to the Rule of Law in Burundi
column17: 05 February. The FARDC was deployed to the Kigoma region of Uvira in response to the presence of Red TABARA. Upon learning of the deployment, the armed group fled the area and the FARDC has reestablished government control of the region.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 05 February. FARDC forces attacked three Mayi Mayi Charles combatants in Buramba, Rutshuru. One Mayi Mayi member was killed and weapons were seized.

column6: UPLC: Union of Patriots for the Liberation of Congo
column17: 05 February. The UPLC attacked the Kasitu (no coordinates available) health center in the Vuhovi area. The attackers burned the mattresses in the center.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: RED-TABARA: Resistance to the Rule of Law in Burundi
column17: Between 6 February and 11 March [coded as 5 events between the period], in Uvira area, Sukola II operation led by FARDC against local and foreign-armed groups, including RED Tabara resulted in 37 enemy combatant casualties and the capture or surrender of 52 combatants and the recovery of their weapons and ammunition. Twelve related-fatalities separately recoded, remaining 25 spread between 5 events during the time frame.
06 February. University of Kisangani students demonstrated calling for the release of two students arrested in a murder case. The demonstrators burned school and teacher vehicles.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 07 February (on or around). The corpse of a woman was found in Ariwara, Ituri. The victim's genitals had been removed. Some locals believe the genitals were removed for ritualistic purposes.

column9: Teachers (Democratic Republic of Congo); Women (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 07 February. Students at the University of Kisangani, who rioted over the arrest of two students the day prior, continued to destroy property. The students attacked professor's homes and property. One woman was reportedly assaulted by the rioters.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: Around 7 February 2019 (as reported), the body of a handcuffed man was found lifeless in the Loulo river in Mabalako (Beni, Nord-Kivu) after being detained by the PNC. The military reported that their death came after they were liberated by a Mayi-Mayi militia.

column9: Batwa Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 7 February 2019, presumed ADF fighters attacked four people, three of whom were Batwa, in Mavivi (Beni, Nord-Kivu).
On 7 February 2019, presumed ADF fighters attacked Rwangoma quarter in Beni city (Beni, Nord-Kivu), raping a woman and killing seven people. 7 people were also kidnapped.

07 February (on or before). An armed group (likely the ADF due to the presence of children and women within the armed group) attacked Rwangoma. The FARDC reportedly repelled the attackers (clash coded separately) but residents reported hearing gunfire into the next morning. At least four civilian fatalities were reported (other sources indicated seven). The attackers also looted civilian property and abducted four adults and four children - the body of one of the abductees was found near Bwerera a few days later.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 07 February. LUCHA members demonstrated in Goma against a barrier at the port. Police intervened and arrested seven demonstrators.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 07 February. ADF combatants attacked the FARDC in the Mbua Kamango region.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column16: Radio Okapi; Kivu Security Tracker; UN (unspecified); Radio Moto
column17: On 7 February, in Rwangoma, an unidentified armed group (likely the ADF due to the presence of children and women within the armed group) attacked civilians, killing 6, injuring 2, abducting 8, including 6 children. The FARDC reportedly repelled the attackers but residents reported hearing gunfire into the next morning. The body of one of the abductees was found near Bwerera a few days later.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 07 February. A group of Mayi Mayi set fire to a FARDC site in Buzumba (no coordinates available), Masisi.

column6: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: 08 February. MONUSCO launched an offensive against the ADF in the Mayangose Forest (no coordinates available) in Beni.

column9: Batwa Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 08 February. Suspected ADF combatants killed three pygmies in Mavivi, Oicha.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Aid Workers (Democratic Republic of Congo); MSF: Doctors Without Borders
column17: 08 February. An unidentified armed group abducted two MSF employees from Bitoy (no coordinates available near Masisi town). The assailants released the abductees later that evening.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 08 February. An unidentified armed group attacked Mundiba. The group killed one elderly man and injured his wife. The perpetrators also set four houses on fire.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 08 February. Approximately 140 Kamwina Nsapu combatants voluntarily disarmed in Kamako. Female youth were among the group participating in disarmament.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 08 February. The FARDC clashed with an armed group in Nyolo (no coordinates available), in the Djugu territory. The armed group has been utilizing the town as a base for launching attacks in the territory.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-) Prison Guards
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 08 February. Prisoners escaped from the Tshikapa prison. The prisoners injured a guard and stole his gun as they escaped through a hole in a wall. Nine prisoners were killed as guards attempted to capture them, two police and two former militia members were also killed. Eight other escapees were injured.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 08 February. The FDLR-FOCA attacked a FARDC site at Itabi (no coordinate available, located in Masisi). The attackers beheaded two soldiers.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: FDLR-FOCA: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda- Forces fighting Abacunguzi
column17: 08 February. FDLR FOCA forces attacked the FARDC in Tabi (no coordinates available, in the Burungu region) Masisi territory, killing three soldiers.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: On 8 February, at PK 9 road near Mbau, an unidentified armed group clashed with FARDC, killing 2 and injuring 3 soldiers (no further details available).

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 08 February. A woman was shot and killed by unidentified perpetrators in Urii, Mahagi (no coordinates available, 19 km from Mahagi town). The assailants also removed the woman's genitals. Her body was discovered the following day. Local residents believe the genitals were removed for ritualistic purposes.

08 February 2019. Raia Mutomboki- Kokodikoko attacked Kabikokole, Mwenga (coordinates are approximate). The assailants reportedly raped 100 women. They also looted the town and burned a health center.
On 8 February, in Kudukudu, ADF attacked civilians, killing 4, including a child and injuring 2.

09 February. LRA attacked civilians near Bulumasi, Bas Uele. They killed a man from CAR and abducted 12 civilians, including three women and two children. The abductees, with the exception of one of the boys were released on 11/02.
On 9 February 2019, elements of the Mayi Mayi Nduma militia killed a man in Mambale village (Beni, Nord-Kivu).

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 01-28 February. 58 women and one child experienced conflict-related sexual violence in the DRC during the month of February. Coded as one attack per week.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: On 9 Feb 2019, an FARDC soldier killed a woman with a machete in Lyakobo neighborhood of Beni town. The FARDC soldier attempted to rape the victim who resisted.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 09 February (on or around). During the weekend, FARDC forces destroyed a rebel training center in the Wango forest, near Largu. The attack was part of an operation against the group operating in the Djugu territory. Six rebels were killed during the three hours of clashes.
10 February. Nyatura combatants clashed with the NDC-Renove in Nyampanika and Kashanje (no coordinates available for either village, coded as one event at Mokoto prec2), in the Bashali region.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 10 February. Unidentified armed men abducted a man near Bunyangula, Rutshuru (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). The abductee was on his way to pay a ransom for other hostages. The assailants demanded a ransom for the abductee.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 10 February. An unidentified armed group attacked a FARDC base in Kiteraga, Oicha. The assailants set fire to the military site and injured one soldier.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 10 February. An unidentified armed group attacked two soldiers at a checkpoint in Busalali, Beni (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map) killing one of the soldiers and injuring the other.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 10 February. A soldier was killed by an unidentified armed group in Vusalali (no coordinates available), in the Bashu region.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column9: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: 10 February (on or around). An unidentified armed group ambushed MONUSCO and FARDC forces along the Beni-Butembo road.

column9: Health Workers (Democratic Republic of Congo); Aid Workers (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 11 February. Local residents in Mavono, Butembo set fire to the Ebola health center in the town. Reasons unclear.
On 11 February 2019, two people were killed during an incursion by presumed ADF fighters into Mamove village (Beni, Nord-Kivu).

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 11 February. The ADF attacked an FARDC position in Mamove, Beni. The rebels also looted the town and attempted to abduct civilians. Local civil society organizations report four rebels killed and four abductees freed. The military reported a dozen rebel fatalities (coded at lowest estimate).
11 February. Mayi Mayi Mbulu abducted a man from Ngendo, Uvira (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). The assailants demanded a $2,000 ransom.

column6: FDLR-RUD: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda-Rally for Unity and Democracy
column17: 11 February. FDLR-RUD combatants abducted a man from Mirumba, Rutshuru (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). The assailants demanded a ransom.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 11 February. An unidentified armed group attacked the FARDC in Ndombi, Oicha.
11 February. Mayi Mayi Mwenyemali abducted two people from Nyamugali, Uvira. The assailants demanded a ransom of $2,500.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 28 January - 02 April: The FARDC launched operations against the Mayi Mayi Simba in the Babila Babombi and Bombo communes of Mambasa territory. 38 Mayi Mayi Simba were killed during the period. 12 are coded in Mapendano on 01/03. The remaining 26 fatalities are spread between 8 events during the time period (one battle per week).

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: On 11 February, in Mayimoya, unidentified armed group clashed with FARDC, killing 1 soldier.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: NDC-R: Nduma Defence of Congo (Renewal); Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura-Kavumbi); Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura) Bohoza Faction
column17: 01 January - 28 March. The NDC-R, Nyatura Kibumba, and Nyatura Bohoza raped separately at least 57 women in the Bashali-Mokoto territory, leaving three killed. Two attacks occurred on 14/01. The remaining attacks were coded as one event per week over the mentioned period (12 events). Women were most frequently attacked by combatants while tending to their fields. A number of armed groups are vying for control of the territory.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: UPLC: Union of Patriots for the Liberation of Congo
column17: 11 February. Three FARDC soldiers were killed in Mataba, Beni by suspected UPLC combatants.
12 February (on or before). Over the course of a few days, approximately 5,000 refugees fleeing violence in South Sudan crossed into Congolese villages along the border, near Ingbokolo.

column9: FCC: Common Front for Congo; CCU: United Congolese Convention
column17: 12 February. Justin Omookala, of the CCU, held a governorship campaign march in Lusambo, Sankuru. Youth from the FCC opposition threw rocks at the CCU members. Some sources indicate that the groups began street fighting and the police intervened with live ammunition, killing one and injuring others. However, other sources reported that Justin Omookala's bodyguard shot at the opposition, resulting in the death and injuries.

column6: Bakeka Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Bakeka Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 12 February. A clash occurred in Mituku-Bamoya (no coordinates available, located in the Ubundu territory) between supporters of the new Bakeka groupment leader and supporters of the old leader. The clash resulted in several wounded from machetes.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-) Eco-Guards
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 12 February. An unidentified armed group attacked national park guards in Museya, Beni. The guards, along with the FARDC, repelled the attackers, killing two.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 12 February. Mayi Mayi Mesandu forces seized control of Lowa, Tshopo forcing the FARDC to withdraw from the city. Most of the civilian population also fled.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 12 February. A soldier killed a civilian in Kibongo (no coordinates available), near Nyamilima, after the civilian refused to transport the soldier's belongings.

column6: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 12 February. A Batwa militia attacked Amiko (no coordinates available; in the Bendera region). The group looted the village and abducted women, who they took into the bush to rape. The abductees were later released.
13 February (on or before). Disarmed Nsapu militia members occupied the Kamako primary school and imposed taxes and arbitrary arrests on the civilian population in Kamako.
13 February. ADF combatants killed three civilians traveling to Mamove, on the Oicha-Mamove road.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 13 February, in Mulolya, an unidentified armed group attacked civilians, killing 2. 1 civilian was reported missing.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: RED-TABARA: Resistance to the Rule of Law in Burundi
column17: Between 6 February and 11 March [coded as 5 events between the period], in Uvira area, Sukola II operation led by FARDC against local and foreign-armed groups, including RED Tabara resulted in 37 enemy combatant casualties and the capture or surrender of 52 combatants and the recovery of their weapons and ammunition.
13 February. At least 200 nurses and health care workers from the Uvira territory gathered in Bukavu to demand over-due benefits.
14 February. FNL rebels ambushed two buses in Kagunga, Uvira. Two people were killed and 14 were injured.
14 February. Residents of Rwangoma and LUCHA members protested, calling for increased security and the release of those abducted during the 07/02 attacks on the town.

column7: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 14 February. Police officers in Beni shot into the air in protest of their salary payments, which was less than they had expected. Those responsible were arrested.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: On 14 February, in Oicha, an unidentified armed group clashed with FARDC. 1 soldier has been injured and 1 civilian killed.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 14 February. The FARDC attacked the Mayi Mayi Mbulu near Ngendo, Uvira (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). The military killed three militia members and freed a hostage (who was abducted by the group on 11/02).
15 February. Artisanal miners protested in Rubaya and Gakombe (no coordinates available) against a reduction in their salaries.

column8: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column17: 15 February. The NDC-Renove clashed with APCLS and Nyatura-Jean Marie forces in Hembe, Masisi (coordinates are approximate based on OCHA map). Five combatants were killed and six people were wounded, including three civilians.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: February (month of), an unidentified armed group abducted four girls between 4 and 7 years old from Kajuchu, Kabare (no coordinates available). Three days after their abduction their bodies were found, with their genitals removed.

column6: CNRD: National Council for Renewal and Democracy
column17: In February [coded to 15 February], near Rutare, a group of approximately 4000 CNRD elements established new base.

15 February. Residents of Masisi and Nyabiondo protested calling for the restoration of security in the region and the resumption of medical services by MSF - who suspended activities in the region after staff members were temporarily abducted.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 15 February. FARDC forces, on the Congo River bank outside of Lowa, Tsopo fired at Mayi Mayi Mesandu forces, who took control of Lowa a few days prior.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column9: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 15 February. Angry residents attacked a hand washing station - a part of the Ebola response - in Mambasa, Ituri. The residents opposed the Ebola vaccination campaign and were angry that locals were not hired as part of the response. Soldiers and police responded by firing into the air to disperse the group. A woman was injured by a stray bullet.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 15 February. The FARDC killed two ADF leaders - Kibuye Kajuju (aka Kadjadju and Canada) and Richard Mugisa (aka MTM)- in Mamove, Oicha.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 15 February. 25 Mayi Mayi Reunion members voluntarily disarmed at the FARDC base in Mboko. Another 14 Mayi Mayi combatants surrendered to the FARDC on the 17th in Lusambo, Fizi.
15 February. Raia Mutomboki-Shukuru attacked Rumondo, Kalehe and abducted four boys.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 16 February. An unidentified armed group attacked the Mugunga and Majengo neighborhoods of Goma. The attackers killed six civilians. A military uniform was later discovered near Virunga National Park where the assailants fled after the attack.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 16 February. An unidentified armed group (believed to be the same group which attacked Goma town) killed two civilians in the Nyiragongo territory. After the attacks the group reportedly fled into Virunga National Park.
16 February. NDC-Renove forces attacked the Mayi Mayi Kavumbi in Lwama, Masisi in an effort to gain control of the town.
16 February. NDC-Renove forces attacked the Nyatura Jean Marie, between Lukweti and Nyange Bibwe, in Masisi.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 01-28 February. 58 women and one child experienced conflict-related sexual violence in the DRC during the month of February. Coded as one attack per week.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: FNL-N: National Forces of Liberation (Nzabampema Faction)
column17: 16 February. The FARDC attacked the FNL Nzabampema in Busisi, Uvira (no coordinates available). Six militia members were killed. The FARDC also burned down their homes.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: On 16 February, in Masilikwede (near Kamango), the ADF clashed with FARDC. 5 soldiers were killed and 3 were injured.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 17 February. The FARDC killed two Mayi Mayi combatants and destroyed Mayi Mayi camps in the Beni territory. Four militia members were captured.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019); MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: 17 February. Mayi Mayi Mazembe attacked a CENI warehouse and a residence owned by Kabila in Beni (unclear if in Beni town or territory). Police, military, and MONUSCO forces repelled the attackers.
17 February. The Raia Mutomboki Lukoba and Ndarumanga ambushed three motorcyclist outside of Nyombe, Shabunda. The assailants looted goods and forced six civilians to carry the goods.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 17 February. A soldier shot and killed another soldier in Ramba. The soldier had reportedly called the perpetrator a Rwandan.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 17 February. The FARDC forced civilians to carry their belongings as they relocated to Kitindi, Shabunda (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map).

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 18 February. An unidentified armed group abducted a nurse from his home in Ishango. His body was later discovered in Graben - inside the Virunga National Park, which many armed groups operate out of. The murder prompted a strike of health workers in the Vuhovi zone over insecurity.
18 February. Mayi Mayi Buhirwa ambushed two passenger vehicles in Rushima (no coordinates available, located between Kiliba and Uvira). The assailants looted the property of the passengers.

18 February. Residents of the Gyamba neighborhood in Bukavu barricaded Road 2, which leads from Bukavu through the Ruzizi border crossing. The residents protested the cut off of their water supply four months prior. No indication of the number of demonstrators.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 18 February, in Ngite, an unidentified armed group attacked civilians, killing 2, injuring 1 and abducting 1.

column7: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 18 February. Approximately 350 police deployed to Uvira in December protested and barricaded highway 5 in Rugenge. The police demonstrated over 3-4 months of backpay which they have not received. The demonstrators reportedly charged civilians to cross through the barricade. Military forces intervened to restore order.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 28 January - 02 April: The FARDC launched operations against the Mayi Mayi Simba in the Babila Babombi and Bombo communes of Mambasa territory. 38 Mayi Mayi Simba were killed during the period. 12 are coded in Mapendano on 01/03. The remaining 26 fatalities are spread between 8 events during the time period (one battle per week).

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 18 February. Mayi Mayi Buhirwa attempted to steal cattle in Kahanda but the FARDC repelled the group.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 18 February. ADF forces attacked Mavivi. The FARDC responded and the groups clashed for two hours. Two civilians were killed.
On 18 February 2019, two people were attacked and injured by presumed ADF fighters in Ngite village (Beni, Nord-Kivu).

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 18 February. The FARDC attacked the Mayi Mayi Kidjangala in Kanga, Uvira. Two militia members were killed during the operations in Kabere, Kanga, and Kahungu (the fatalities were disaggregated between locations).

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 18 February. The FARDC attacked the Mayi Mayi Kidjangala in Kabere, Uvira. Two militia members were killed during the operations in Kabere, Kanga, and Kahungu (the fatalities were disaggregated between locations).

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
