column17: 18 February. The FARDC attacked the Mayi Mayi Kidjangala in Kahungu, Uvira. Two militia members were killed during the operations in Kabere, Kanga, and Kahungu (the fatalities were disaggregated between locations).

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: NDC-R: Nduma Defence of Congo (Renewal); Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura-Kavumbi); Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura) Bohoza Faction
column17: 01 January - 28 March. The NDC-R, Nyatura Kibumba, and Nyatura Bohoza raped separately at least 57 women in the Bashali-Mokoto territory, leaving three killed. Two attacks occurred on 14/01. The remaining attacks were coded as one event per week over the mentioned period (12 events). Women were most frequently attacked by combatants while tending to their fields. A number of armed groups are vying for control of the territory.
19 February 2019. The LRA looted food and other items from Aaru, Haut-Uele.
19 February 2019. The LRA looted seven civilians along the road 3 km west of Kpaika, Dungu.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 19 February 2019. Two armed men ambushed a motorbike near Digba, Ango. The assailants tied the driver to a tree and raped the two female passengers. They also looted the victims.

column9: Luba Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 19 February 2019. Bana Mura combatants attacked and killed 15 Luba civilians, including six women, in Tshiniota, Kasai (no coordinates available). The attack followed broadcasts by Chokwe journalists on radio stations calling for violence.
On 19 February 2019, the NDC militia killed a man in Kabasha village (Beni, Nord-Kivu).

19 February. Residents of the Gyamba neighborhood in Bukavu barricaded Road 2, which leads from Bukavu through the Ruzizi border crossing, for a second day. The residents protested the cut off of their water supply four months prior. [size=no report]

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 19 February. Unidentified gunmen killed a man in Kagunga, Uvira. Local sources believe the attack may have stemmed from witchcraft accusations.

column7: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 19 February. Approximately 300 police officers demonstrated in Gbadolite over three months of back payments owed to them.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 19 February. The FARDC captured an ADF fighter in Gawa, Beni. They also seized a machine gun.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 19 February. The NDC-Renove attacked the FARDC, as they were attempting to establish a base in Kyuto, Lubero (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). The NDC-R forced the FARDC to retreat from the town. Five soldiers were killed and one militia member was wounded.

column6: APCLS-M: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo (Mapenzi)
column9: Loashi Communal Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 19 February. The APCLS-Mapenzi tortured the Loashi village chief, who died from his injuries.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 20 February. The FARDC attacked Mayi Mayi PRM forces during operations in the Vurondo-Museya area, as part of larger operations in Lubero (Vurondo and Museya are located along the border between Beni and Lubero). Two militia members were killed, some sources reported four fatalities.

20 February. Residents of the Gyamba neighborhood in Bukavu barricaded Road 2, which leads from Bukavu through the Ruzizi border crossing, for a third day. The residents are protesting the cut off of their water supply four months prior. [size=no report]

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 20 February. An unidentified armed group killed three people in Bugamba, near Goma. The assailants also abducted civilians.

column7: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 20 February. 'Several hundred' police officers protested in Bukavu over delayed salary payments.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 20 February. Police dispersed supporters of Hubert Kishabongo, who had gathered at a hearing in Kindu. The demonstrators gathered for a hearing related to Kishabongo's judicial challenge to CENI's governorship results in Maniema. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: RED-TABARA: Resistance to the Rule of Law in Burundi
column17: Between 6 February and 11 March [coded as 5 events between the period], in Uvira area, Sukola II operation led by FARDC against local and foreign-armed groups, including RED Tabara resulted in 37 enemy combatant casualties and the capture or surrender of 52 combatants and the recovery of their weapons and ammunition.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 20 February. The FARDC launched an attack on Mayi Mayi forces along the Karuruma-Kyavinyonge road in Virunga National Park. Three Mayi Mayi were killed and two were captured.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 20 February. An unidentified armed group abducted a man from Kambake, Beni (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). The perpetrators demanded a ransom.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 21 February. During the evening, unidentified armed men attacked Ndosho. The perpetrators killed three people during the attack and abducted 11 others. At least one body, some sources indicate three, of the abductees were later found.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 21 February (on or before). Kihebe Ngabunga, leader of the Mayi Mayi Kihebe (which operates in the Mulenge area of Uvira) along with seven of his followers surrendered to the FARDC.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 21 February (on or around). Police assaulted to suspects they were apprehending in Ndolo Mayimbu (no coordinates available, in the Lueta area), leading to clashes with armed residents (coded separately).

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 21 February. Residents of Ndolo Mayimbu (no coordinates available, in the Lueta area) attacked two police officers with machetes after they assaulted the suspects they were apprehending (coded separately). One police officer was killed and the other was injured.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 21 February. The FARDC regained control of Lowa town from the Mayi Mayi Mesandu.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 21 February. The FARDC regained control of Masimango village from the Mayi Mayi Mesandu.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 21 February. The FARDC regained control of Kirundu village from the Mayi Mayi Mesandu.
21 February. Students from schools in the Ndosho area of Goma, protested in the city against insecurity in the area. The protests came the day after an attack on the area. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 21 February. A police officer shot and killed another officer and a detainee in Busumba, Masisi. The assailant then killed himself.

column8: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column9: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura-Kavumbi); Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura); APCLS-M: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo (Mapenzi)
column17: 21 February. The NDC-Renove clashed with the APCLS and a coalition of Nyatura groups led by Kavumbi in and around Katoko, Bashali (no coordinates available). Four civilians, three NDC-R combatants and four from the APCLS/Nyatura coalition were killed. Mapenzi, the leader of Ndimendime was also injured. Three women were abducted by the NDC-R, along with two Nyatura combatants. Two children were also reported missing since the clashes.

column7: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 22 February. Police in the Kamalenga neighborhood of Tshikapa fired shots into the air while demanding their over due salaries. The officers were part of a contingent of 250 reinforcements deployed to the area for elections. 11 arrests were made, it is unclear how many participated in the demonstration.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 22 February 2019. The Mayi Mayi Mazembe attacked the FARDC in Kikere, Beni (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). The FARDC shot and killed a civilian, who they mistook for a combatant.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 22 February 2019. An unidentified armed group attempted to loot civilians near Kitemesho. The FARDC was alerted and repelled the attackers.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 01-28 February. 58 women and one child experienced conflict-related sexual violence in the DRC during the month of February. Coded as one attack per week.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 23 February. A soldier raped a woman in Ngora, Walikale.

column8: Bakeka Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 24 February (on or around). The FARDC clashed with a Bakeka communal militia, led by Modeste Bahati, in Lowa and nearby areas (coded as 2 events, one with Lowa geo precision 1 and one with geo precision 2). Four militia members were killed, and some sources report one military fatality (spread across the two events). Local civil society organizations indicated that the FARDC does not distinguish between civilians and militia members and has utilized the populations of Babuma and Bayelo villages to loot Lowa.

column9: Tetela Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 24 February (on or before). Kamwina Nsapu abducted a Tetela community leader in Kamako. After initially disarming, Kamwina Nsapu militia members in Kamako have extorted the Tetela community.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 24 February. Two soldiers shot and killed a motorbike driver in Mangboko, Beni as he was taking them from Beni to Mbau.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 24 February. The FARDC clashed with Kamwina Nsapu militia members in Kamako, Kasai. The clash occurred as a local administrator, accompanied by soldiers, went to the home of a Kamwina Nsapu leader to secure the release of an abducted Tetela community leader. The militia reportedly resisted and surrounded the administrator, prompting the FARDC to open fire. Fatalities reported by the hospital reached 19.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 24 February 2019. Four unidentified armed men abducted a man from Kibanga, Uvira. The assailants demanded a $2,000 ransom.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column17: 24 February 2019. During the night, an unidentified armed group attempted to raid a home in the Kyeshero neighborhood of Goma. A police officer repelled the assailants but was injured during the clash.

column17: 24 February. During the night, a suspected group of Mayi Mayi set the Ebola treatment center (operated by MSF) in Katwa, Butembo on fire. One security guard died while trying to escape. 25 February. Motorbike drivers protested in Beni following the murder of a colleague by soldiers the day prior. [size=no report]

column17: On 25 February 2019, a professional biker was killed by two loyalist soldiers in Mangboko village (Beni, Nord-Kivu). One of the perpetrators was later apprehended by residents and handed over to the authorities.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: On 25 February 2019, local residents apprehended a soldier and took him to the authorities in Mangboko village (Beni, Nord-Kivu) after two soldiers had killed a professional biker. [size=no report]

column17: 25 February. Following a clash between the FARDC and Kamwina Nsapu members in Kamako the day before, the FARDC along with Bana Mura militia members and Tetela's, armed with shotguns and machetes began patrolling Kamako.

column9: Bafuliru Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo); Banyindu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo); Babembe Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 26 February - 08 March. The Twiganeho and Gumino militias (both are Banyamulenge) clashed with Mayi Mayi groups from the Bafuliru, Banyindu, and Babembe ethnic groups in the Minembwe region (between the borders of Mwenga and Fizi). Attacks were carried out on civilians in villages in the region, including lootings and the destruction of at least six villages. 27 fatalities were reported as a result of the inter-communal violence. The fatalities were spread across incidents including clashes and attacks on civilians.

26 February. The NDC-Renove clashed with a Nyatura group in the Bashali territory, prompting residents of Rugarama, Kashanje, and Nyampanika to flee (no coordinates available for any of the villages - coded as Lwama prec2).

26 February. 60 former M23 members were voluntarily repatriated from Uganda to Goma. The dependents of the former militia members will be able to return to their families, while the former militia members will have the choice between programs for military integration or civilian integration.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: On 26 February, in Atokaka, an unidentified armed group clashed with FARDC, killing 1 and injuring 2 soldiers (no further details available).

column17: On 26 February, in Mulolya, an unidentified armed group attacked civilians, killing 3, injuring 2 and abducting 23, including 4 children. Later reports indicate 22 out of 23 abducted civilians were released on 5 March.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: On 26 February, in Ngite, The ADF launched an attack on the FARDC. The clash resulted in injuring of 2 FARDC soldiers.

column17: 26 February 2019. Two unidentified armed men robbed a vehicle, looted property, and abducted two men near Kitemesho, Uvira.

column17: 27 February. Civil society organizations demonstrated in Kinshasa, calling for Kabila to be held accountable for any crimes he committed. 30 demonstrators were arrested. [size=no report]

column6: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 03 January. An armed Batwa militia ambushed a candidate from Kongolo's convoy on their way to Lubumbashi on the Kalemie-Kabwela-Pweto-Lubumbashi road. Two people were killed and another was injured.

01 March. Despite attacks against them during the night, 50 merchants from Kadutu demonstrated in Bukavu after they were evicted from the market, which was reportedly sold by authorities. The demonstrators barricaded a road and burned tires. [size=50]

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 01 March. The FARDC attacked a Mayi Mayi Simba position in Mapendano, Mombo commune, Ituri (no coordinates available). The FARDC regained control of the village, which the armed group had occupied. 12 militia members were killed during the clash.

column6: Unidentified Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 01 March (on or around). As inter-communal clashes occurred in the Minembwe region (between the borders of Fizi and Mwenga), houses were burned down in Bibiza I (no coordinates available), displacing the local community. Unclear which communal group the perpetrators belonged to.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 02 March. An unidentified armed group shot and killed five civilians and one soldier in the Ndosho and Bugamba areas of Goma. The combatants also abducted one man, some sources indicate 13 people were abducted. The attackers demanded a $10,000 ransom. Coded as two events, one battle, one VAC.

column6: Unidentified Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 02 March (on or around). As inter-ethnic clashes occurred in the Minembwe area (on the border of Fizi and Mwenga), one of the militias looted cattle in Matanganyika (no coordinates available).
02 March 2019. The LRA ambushed civilians 5 km north of Kpaika, Dungu. The assailants abducted eight civilians, including a child. They also looted two vehicles.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 02 March. An unidentified armed group abducted 13 farmers in Kiwanja, Rutshuru.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 02 March. An unidentified armed group shot and killed five civilians and one soldier in the Ndosho and Bugamba areas of Goma. The combatants also abducted one man. Coded as two events, one battle, one VAC.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 02 March. The FARDC attacked the Mtetezi (led by Ebuela) base in Kafulo, Fizi. Six people killed - some sources indicate all militia members others indicate four militia members and two civilians - and weapons were seized.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 02 March. A police officer opened fire in the Maroc market in Yumbi, killing one person and injuring three others. The officer was arrested.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 02 March. The Mayi Mayi Nguru attacked Kyavinyonge, Oicha. The FARDC responded and captured four of the assailants.
03 March. The NDC-Renove clashed with the Nyatura Kavumbi in Bugoyi, Masisi (no coordinates available). 11 people were killed, including six civilians.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 03 March. During the night, a man was stabbed to death in Ndosho, Goma. The town experienced a larger attack on 03/02.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 03 - 07 March. During the week, an unidentified gunman dressed in military fatigues looted the Kabwe Grand Seminary, Dibaya. A priest was injured during the attack.
03 March 2019. The NDC-Renove attacked the Nyatura Domi in Mweso, Masisi. The FARDC intervened to end the clash.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 03 March 2019. Police dispersed protesters in Goma who sought to file a memorandum with the governor over insecurity.

column7: CNPSC: National Coalition of the People for Congo's Sovereignty
column8: Ngumino Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Twiganeho Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo); Banyamulenge Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 03 March 2019. The Mayi Mayi Biloze Bishambuke and CNPSC attacked the Ngumino and Twiganeho militias in Biziba (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map) and Matanganyika (no coordinates available). 32 homes were destroyed and cattle were also looted.

column6: Twiganeho Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Mayi Mayi Militia (Gumino); Banyamulenge Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Bafuliru Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo); Banyindu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo); Babembe Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 26 February - 08 March. The Twiganeho and Gumino militias (both are Banyamulenge) clashed with Mayi Mayi groups from the Bafuliru, Banyindu, and Babembe ethnic groups in the Minembwe region (between the borders of Mwenga and Fizi). Attacks were carried out on civilians in villages in the region, including lootings and the destruction of at least six villages. 27 fatalities were reported as a result of the inter-communal violence. The fatalities were spread across incidents including clashes and attacks on civilians.

column7: LC: Lamuka Coalition; ECIDE: Engagement for Citizenship and Development
column17: 04 March. Fayulu supporters demonstrated in front of the MONUSCO headquarters in Goma, calling for new elections. [size=no report]

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: NDC-R: Nduma Defence of Congo (Renewal); Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura-Kavumbi); Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura) Bohoza Faction
column17: 01 January - 28 March. The NDC-R, Nyatura Kibumba, and Nyatura Bohoza raped separately at least 57 women in the Bashali-Mokoto territory, leaving three killed. Two attacks occurred on 14/01. The remaining attacks were coded as one event per week over the mentioned period (12 events). Women were most frequently attacked by combatants while tending to their fields. A number of armed groups are vying for control of the territory.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 04 March. During the night, an unidentified armed group beheaded at least two people (some sources indicate three) in the Majengo neighborhood of Goma.
05 March 2019. An LRA group, looted five civilians along the Banda-Dakwa road, near Mugalie. The assailants held the victims captive for several hours before releasing them.
05 March 2019. The LRA attacked Madi, Bas-Uele (coordinates are approximate based on location 10 km west of Mugalie). The assailants looted the town and abducted a woman and baby.
05 March. LUCHA members protested in front of the Tshikapa Assembly building, calling for politicians to act in the interest of the population. [size=no report]
05 March. Youth protested against insecurity in Kalemie, following a robbery the night before. [size=100]

column6: AFPR: Alliance of Patriotic Resistance Force
column7: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki); Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki-Ngubito)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 02-05 March. 140 Raia Mutomboki combatants of different factions, aligned to the AFPR, surrendered in Minova and Numbi of Kalehe as many of the leaders of AFPR are planning to demobilize. Alphonse Kabishula, leader of the Raia Mutomboki Ngubito and AFPR coalition, along with approximately 100 militiamen surrendered in Minova and Numbi on March 2nd and 5th.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: RED-TABARA: Resistance to the Rule of Law in Burundi
column17: Between 6 February and 11 March [coded as 5 events between the period], in Uvira area, Sukola II operation led by FARDC against local and foreign-armed groups, including RED Tabara resulted in 37 enemy combatant casualties and the capture or surrender of 52 combatants and the recovery of their weapons and ammunition. Twelve related-fatalities separately recoded, remaining 25 spread between 5 events during the time frame.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 05 March. A Mayi Mayi militia attacked a FARDC base in Kitakandya, Butembo (no coordinates available). Two soldiers and one Mayi Mayi combatant were killed.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 05 March. Locals demonstrated in Goma following attacks on Ndosho and Majengo the night before. The demonstrators barricaded roads. The police intervened to restore normalcy. [size=no report]

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 5 March, in Mapobu (aka Kisiki), an unidentified armed group attacked civilians (no further details available).

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 05 March 2019. Following clashes with an armed group in Butembo (coded separately), the FARDC looted civilians.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 05 March 2019. Police and soldiers shot and killed a man in Cibanda, Mwenga (coordinates for Cibanda school used prec1), after he resisted arrest. The security forces injured five other youth.

Attacks were carried out on civilians in villages in the region, including lootings and the destruction of at least six villages. 27 fatalities were reported as a result of the inter-communal violence. The fatalities were spread across incidents including clashes and attacks on civilians.
06 March 2019. The LRA looted Nayule, Ango (coordinates are approximate based on location 7 km south-west of Mugalie). Much of the civilian population fled.

column7: LUCHA: Fight for Change; ECCHA: Citizen Engagement for Change
column17: 06 March. LUCHA and ECHA members demonstrated against Governor Kimbuta and the candidates, Maglorie Kambemba and Gentiny Ngobila. The demonstrators stormed the Provincial Assembly in Kinshasa to denounce the politicians. [size=no report]
06 March. Journalists from Digital Congo protested in Kinshasa over their delayed salary payments. [size=no report]

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 07 March. Students of UOM in Mbuji Mayi demonstrated over a dispute on the transfer of the Dipumba hospital to the university. The demonstrators blocked the entrance to the university and burned tires. Police intervened with tear gas and shots were heard. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 07 March. Following clashes the day prior in the Minembwe area, the FARDC was deployed to Mukera, Fizi in order to restore order in the region.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 07 March. During the night, a soldier was killed by unknown perpetrators in the Bujovu neighborhood of Goma.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 07 March. An unidentified armed group shot two civilians and a soldier who was traveling alone on a motorbike in the Ngandja district of Fizi. The soldier and one of the civilians died.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-) Eco-Guards
column17: 07 March. A Mayi Mayi militia clashed with park rangers at Chanika (no coordinates available), in Virunga National Park. One park ranger was killed.
On 7 March, in Apetinasana, suspected ADF militiamen attacked civilians, killing 1 and abducting 33. 23 of the kidnapped civilians were released on 12 March 2019.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 07 March 2019. The Raia Mutomboki Musumbu and Raia Mutomboki Makindu attacked Itula-Katembele, Shabunda. The militias abducted four police, eight men, and three girls. The assailants raped the three abducted girls. They also stole four weapons.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 07 March 2019. An unidentified armed group attempted to raid cattle in Mutarule. The FARDC responded to repel the assailants. A 16 year-old girl was injured during the clash.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-) Eco-Guards
column17: 07 March 2019. The Mayi Mayi Charles attacked park rangers stationed at Kyanika, Lubero (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). One park ranger was killed and several others were injured.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 07 March 2019. The Mayi Mayi Mwenyemali attempted to raid cattle near Kahanda but were repelled by the FARDC.

08 March. During the night, suspected ADF forces attacked Lubwasi, Beni (no coordinates available; near Beni town). At least six civilians were killed. The perpetrators burned down several houses and a health clinic.
08 March 2019. Women in Dungu protested insecurity in the region and delivered a memorandum to the head of the territory. [size=no report]

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 08 March 2019. The FDLR-FOCA attempted to loot a vehicle near Nyabirehe, but the FARDC intervened and clashed with the assailants. Six people were injured.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 08 March 2019. The FDLR-FOCA attacked the FARDC in Bugomba, Rutshuru (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). The FARDC repelled and chased the assailants.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 08 March 2019. An unidentified armed group attacked Katale, Masisi. The assailants killed two men and injured one other.

column6: Twiganeho Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Bafuliru Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 09 March. A Twiganeho militia set fire to 22 houses in two Kisombe villages, in the Minembwe area. Two people, who were unable to escape their homes died in the fires.

09 March 2019. After clashing with the FARDC, the ADF returned to Apetina, Oicha (no coordinates available) and abducted approximately a dozen civilians. Many of the abductees were released with a group of 23 hostages on 12/03.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 09 March. Mayi Mayi combatants attacked an Ebola treatment center in Butembo. The assailants clashed with police. One police officer was killed and one Mayi Mayi was injured.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 09 March 2019. The ADF clashed with the FARDC in Apetina, Oicha (no coordinates available).

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 09 March 2019. The Nyatura Domi attacked Mweso, Masisi and clashed with the police. One officer was injured and one was abducted.
10 March 2019. The LRA group which attacked Naparka on 09/03, attacked the Dingilo mine (18 km from Naparka). The assailants injured one man and looted the mine.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column9: Christian Group (Democratic Republic of Congo); Women (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 10 March 2019. Unidentified armed men wearing police uniforms (coded as police) robbed a convent run by nuns in Tshimbulu, Dibaya. The assailants stole $1,500, as well as computers and other valuables.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 10 March 2019 (on or before). The FARDC regained control of Mweso town from the Nyatura-Domi. Civilians were injured during the clash.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 10 March, near Oicha, in Kegele, an unidentified armed group abducted 11 civilians.

column17: 10 March 2019. During the night, an unidentified armed group abducted a professor and student in Rutshuru.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 11 March 2019. The FARDC forced 11 men to carry their belongings when they left Kitindi, Shabunda. No indication if the abductees were released.

column17: 12 March 2019. The Nyatura Kavumbi attacked a FARDC position in Kahira, Masisi. The military repelled and pursued the assailants.

13 March 2019. Residents of Yumbi protested against the appointment of a new territorial administrator from Inongo. The protesters are concerned that he will reignite communal violence in Yumbi. [size=no report]

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)

column9: Health Workers (Democratic Republic of Congo); WHO: World Health Organization
column17: 14 March 2019. Angry locals attacked an Ebola clinic in Mamboa, Lubero (no coordinates available). The rioters set fire to the treatment center and stoned vehicles at the facility after health workers attempted to take a blood sample from a child who had died. The rioters also set fire to the home of a local official whom they blamed for alerting the health workers to the death. Police intervened and fired shots to disperse the rioters, killing a passer-by and injuring one demonstrator. [size=no report]

14 March 2019. The Raia Mutomboki Shabani attacked Lungomangoma (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map) and Miruwa (no coordinates available), Kalehe. The assailants looted food items and livestock. They used six male civilians as porters for the stolen goods, no indication if they were later released.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 14 March 2019. An unidentified armed group shot and killed a soldier in the Kamesimbonzo neighborhood in Butembo. The assailants also stole the soldier's AK-47.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 14 March 2019. Unidentified armed men abducted a woman from Kitevya, Oicha. Many armed groups are active in the area.

Women were most frequently attacked by combatants while tending to their fields. A number of armed groups are vying for control of the territory.

The assailants reportedly came from and returned to Virunga National Park. Some sources indicate 10 people were abducted, five of whom were later killed.

column17: 07 April 2019. A group of Mbororo assaulted the chief of Tadra, prompting locals armed with knives and arrows to attack the Mbororo. One Mbororo was killed and two were wounded.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 07 April 2019. An unidentified armed group abducted a student from Goma. The assailants demanded a $6,000 ransom.

07 April 2019 (on or around). In early April, the Mayi Mayi Mazembe abducted a man from the Kanyabayonga area after accusing him of not participating in communal labor for the militia. The assailants took the man to their camp and severely beat him. He later died from the injuries at the hospital.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 08 April 2019. 29 Raia Mutomboki-Kokodikoko combatants surrendered to the FARDC in the Shabunda territory.

08 April 2019. A group of locals caught eight suspected criminals, who were believed to have killed a man during robberies in the early morning. The angry mob killed four of the suspects. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 08 April 2019. The FARDC attacked an unidentified armed group, which was trying to cross the border from Burundi near Katogota. Two militia members were killed.

column6: FDLR-RUD: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda-Rally for Unity and Democracy
column17: 08 April 2019. The FDLR-RUD abducted three men near Rukoro, Rutshuru. The assailants demanded a $5,000 ransom.
08 April 2019. Two groups of supporters for different governor candidates fought and threw objects at each other in Kinshasa. [size=no report]

column7: UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column9: PPRD: Peoples Party for Reconstruction and Democracy

column17: 08 April 2019. The NDC-Renove clashed with the APCLS in Butemure, Masisi (no coordinates available, near Lwibo).

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 09 April 2019. 350 Mayi Mayi Fimbo na Fimbo surrendered in Musenge, Tanganyika (no coordinates available, 30 km from Kalemie). The second in command of the militia also surrendered.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 09 April 2019. The FARDC carried out operations against the FNL and FOREBU militias in Magunda, Mangwa, and Ruminako (no coordinates available). Three soldiers and 36 militia members - including two senior officers were killed in three days of operations in the areas. The fatalities were spread across the events.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column17: 09 April 2019. The FARDC launched an attack against the APCLS in Showa, Masisi.

column17: 09 April 2019. A group of unidentified armed men ambushed three women between Mangobongobo and the Nyange market, in Ngandja territory. The assailants raped the women and looted their money.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column17: On 10 April 2019, a leader in the community was abducted from his home by unknown armed bandits carrying firearms in Butsili quarter in Beni city (Beni, Nord-Kivu).

column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 11-14 April 2019. An ANR officer, five soldiers, and two relatives of a senator detained and tortured two soldiers, accused of stealing from Senator Muyumba's home in Lubumbashi. The victims had worked as guards for the senator.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: On 11 April, in Kyanimbe (approximately 8 km from Kamango), suspected ADF militiamen clashed with FARDC, injuring 2 soldiers. Additionally, 7 civilians were killed.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 11 April 2019. The FARDC pursued and attacked the Raia Mutomboki Shukuru and Butachibera after they looted a business in Kambegeti, Kalehe (looting coded separately).
11 April 2019. Raia Mutomboki Shukuru and Butachibera looted a store in Kambegeti, Kalehe. The FARDC pursued and attacked them later (clash coded separately).
11 April 2019. Nyatura-Domi combatants abducted and raped a woman from Ihula, Walikale.

column6: FDLR-RUD: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda-Rally for Unity and Democracy
column17: 11 April 2019. FDLR-RUD combatants abducted a 16 year-old male near Kanyisongo, Rutshuru. The assailants demanded a $1,000 ransom.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 12 April 2019. A group of Mayi Mayi entered the Mukunto neighborhood of Lubumbashi. The FARDC repelled the militia, resulting in two Mayi Mayi fatalities.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 12 April 2019. Farmers accidentally set off an abandoned grenade, while tending to their fields in Ndwali, Lubero (no coordinates available). Two people were killed and four were injured.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: 12 April 2019 (on or around). Following the withdrawal of the FARDC from areas within the Irumu territory, the FRPI moved into and occupied Nyasumbi, Palima, and Mbaba (no coordinates available).

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 13 April 2019. An unidentified armed group attacked the Kachange mine, in the Misisi area. Police guarding the mine clashed with the assailants. Two police were killed.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 13 April 2019. The FARDC launched attacks against the Mayi Mayi Reunion in Makyaka (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker), Egoma, and Ma'ama (no coordinates available for Egoma and Ma'ama) in Fizi. Two soldiers and one militia fighter were killed in the clashes.

column6: FDLR-RUD: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda-Rally for Unity and Democracy

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 13 April 2019. An unidentified armed group attacked Django, Djugu (no coordinates available). The assailants killed two people in the village. They abducted a woman and baby, whose bodies were discovered near by the next morning.
13 April 2019. LUCHA activists demonstrated in front of the Airtel office in Butembo against the poor quality of the telecommunication services. [size=no report]
On 14 April 2019, presumed ADF fighters killed two military wives in Bayangala groupment in Watalinga chiefdom (Beni, Nord-Kivu).

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 14 April 2019. An unidentified armed group attacked police forces in the Misisi mining area. The FARDC intervened to assist the police in repelling the attackers. Two police were killed and their weapons were stolen by the attackers.

column6: FNL-N: National Forces of Liberation (Nzabampema Faction)
column17: 14 April 2019. Two FNL-Nzabampema combatants attempted to loot Kashingo, Uvira (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). Mayi Mayi Kashumba attacked and killed the looters.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 15 April 2019. Kavubi Sibomana, along with over 200 of his Nyatura fighters surrendered to the FARDC in Kirumbu, Masisi.

column17: Between January and September 2019 [coded to April], in East of DRC [coded to Goma], OCHA has registered at least 194 kidnapping cases.
15 April 2019. Raia Mutomboki- Hamakombo abducted two men from Katubiro, Kalehe (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map). The assailants demanded a $100 ransom.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 15 April 2019. An unidentified armed group looted homes in Nyange, Fizi (coordinates not known). The assailants abducted several men to carry the stolen goods.
15 April 2019. The Mayi Mayi Reunion attacked Munene, Fizi. The assailants abducted a man and looted money, livestock, and other goods.

End of March - April. Over 12,000 people were displaced in the Kibele region of northern Beni (no coordinates available). Most of the IDPs fled to Kamango and Nobili, which can only be accessed through Uganda due to the insecurity of the region in DRC. Over 60,000 people have reportedly been displaced in North Kivu, particularly the Beni territory during the month of April. Some of the displaced are crossing into Uganda through informal crossings, bypassing immigration and health officials. Humanitarian actors are concerned about the spread of Ebola and access to assistance for those crossing informally.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 15 April 2019 (on or around). An unidentified armed group attacked Luko, Djugu (no coordinates available). The assailants killed four people, including two children.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 15 April 2019. A CENI employee was abducted in Lusambo, Sankuru. The event occurred as governor elections in the province continued to be delayed due to controversy over the single candidate elections.
15 April 2019. Youth in Lodja protested against the postponement of governorship elections in Sankuru. [size=no report]

15 April 2019. Youth from Lokenye neighborhood of Lodja targeted four facilities of the Catholic Church in Lodja, including two schools. They stole goods and attempted to set some of the facilities on fire. The Catholic Church was opposed to the single candidate elections in Sankuru. [size=no report]
15 April 2019. An angry mob assaulted a man in Butembo for going to the bathroom in a public area. The mob accused him of spreading Ebola. [size=no report]
15 April 2019. LUCHA and other civil society organizations demonstrated in Goma against harassment by the provincial government and the customs office. [size=no report]

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 16 April 2019. Suspected ADF attacked FARDC forces in Bovata, North Kivu. Two soldiers were killed and one civilian was injured, some sources repot one civilian fatality as well. The civilian population fled to Kamango. Two days after the attack, the Islamic State claimed responsibility and declared it the Caliphate of the ""Central Africa Province.""

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: On 16 April, near Kamango, a small FARDC camp has been attacked by ADF. During the attack two FARDC soldiers and one civilian were killed.  On 18 April 2019, Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) claimed the attack.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 16 April 2019 (on or before). The FARDC burned several houses and looted property in Kedza and Ndalo, Djugu (no coordinates available, in the Linga area). The attacks prompted residents of the areas to flee.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-) National Intelligence Agency
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 16 April 2019. An angry mob wanted to stone two people who had been arrested by the ANR. The FARDC opened fire to disperse the mob, killing one and injuring three others. [Size=no report]

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 16 April 2019. An unidentified armed group abducted seven people, including two women, from their fields near Kitarama, Rutshuru. The assailants demanded a $5,600 ransom.

column6: UPLC: Union of Patriots for the Liberation of Congo
column17: 16 April 2019. The UPLC abducted a man in Lisasa, Beni.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 16 April 2019. An unidentified armed group attacked Dhendro, Djugu. The assailants set three homes on fire and injured one person. Unarmed local youth chased the assailants, catching one and beatig him to death (pursuit coded separately).

column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 16 April 2019. After an unidentified armed group attacked Dhendro, Djugu (coded in separate event), unarmed local youth chased the assailants, catching one and beatig him to death. [size=no report]

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: 16 April 2019. The FRPI rustled over 200 cattle in Ndoya (no coordinates available; located in the southern part of Irumu). After stealing the cattle, the assailants headed into the forest.

column9: Unidentified Clan Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 16 April 2019. During the week, an armed Burundian militia (likely FNL or FOREBU which are aligned and active in the region), killed a local chief from Basmiukindji, Itombwe (no coordinates available). The Gumino militia reacted forcing hundreds of families to flee the area (assumed clash as the Gumino pursued the rebels - coded separately).

16 April 2019. During the week, likely clash between Gumino and armed Burundian militia (likely FNL or FOREBU which are aligned and active in the region) after they killed a local chief from Basmiukindji, Itombwe (no coordinates available) (coded separately). The violence forced hundreds of families to flee the area.

17 April 2019. Journalists demonstrated in Kinshasa to show their solidarity with Tele 50 journalists, who have been subjected to arrests and police harassment following a labor dispute with their employer. [size=several hundred]

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 17 April 2019. The FARDC abducted a man in Mulobia, Oicha. They also stole $150 from the victim.

column6: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: 17 April 2019. Two MONUSCO contingents were deployed to Lusambo and Lodja, after communal tensions rose regarding the election of the governor of Sankuru.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 18 April 2019. The FARDC launched operations in the Djugu territory to remove barriers, which soldiers established along roads to extort the local population.
18 April 2019. Miners in Rubaya demonstrated against Bisunzu Mining, for not paying the miners for the mineral. The demonstrators also denounced harassment by security officers. [size=no report]

18 April 2019 (on or before). Kabue Ditunga (aka 'General'), who had voluntarily disarmed after the 2018 presidential elections, recruited five male youth in Kananga. Ditunga (who is armed), along with the youth, extort the civilian population of Kananga.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 18 April 2019. In the evening, a group of men armed with knives, entered the Catholic University of Graben in Butembo. The assailants broke windows and blamed the priest for allowing the establishment of an Ebola treatment center in the university's facilities. Mayi Mayi militiamen killed a doctor in the University's clinic the next day (coded in separate event).

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-) Eco-Guards
column17: 18 April 2019 (on or before). Eco-Guards from the Okapi Reserve tortured two men, who they accused of illegally mining in the reserve. According to locals, the victims were traveling between Badengaido and Biakato, when they were falsely accused by the security forces.

column9: Civilians (Cameroon); Health Workers (Democratic Republic of Congo); Health Workers (Cameroon); WHO: World Health Organization
column17: 19 April 2019. A suspected Mayi Mayi group attacked the Catholic University of Graben's Clinic in Butembo, which operates as part of the WHO's Ebola response. The assailants killed a Cameroonian doctor and burned a vehicle. According to a witness, the assailants claimed Ebola was not real and the doctors were killing people by claiming it was.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-) National Intelligence Agency
column17: 19 April 2019. Intelligence officers arrested a woman carrying 23 magazines of ammunition and 690 cartridges in Mulongwe, Uvira. The woman was detained while boarding a bus to Fizi, with the ammunition hidden in her luggage.
20 April 2019. The Raia Mutomboki Walike looted Tchankindo, Shabunda (coordinates not known).

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 20 April 2019. Protesters demonstrated in front of the Airtel office in Butembo, over the communication company's service quality. Police arrested the demonstrators. [size=9]

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 20 April 2019. An FARDC patrol attacked the Raia Mutombi Walike, after they looted Tchankindo (coordinates not known).

column6: Bosonalongo Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Bosozaya Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 20 April 2019. Following the ruling on a land dispute between the Bosonalongo and Bosozaya villages in the Kungu territory, a group of Bosonalongo residents armed with traditional weapons attacked Bosozaya, Kungu (no coordinates available) and clashed with local residents. Three Bosozaya were seriously injured and one Bosonalongo attacker was slightly injured. The attackers burned 43 homes, two schools, and destroyed agricultural fields.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column9: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 20 April 2019. An unidentified armed group attacked an Ebola center in Katwa, Butembo. Security forces thwarted the attack, capturing at least one assailant (some sources indicated five) and killing another.

20 April 2019. Angolan military forces entered Makanga, Lukula (no coordinates available). The security forces were searching for FLEC rebels. During their incursions, which occurred at least twice during April, the forces detained at least four people who they took back to Angola.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 20 April 2019. Soldiers began firing their weapons in Demba around the territorial administration building, following the death of one of their colleagues due to overconsumption of alcohol (the soldiers suspected he was poisoned).

column7: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki-Ngandu); Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki-Mabala)
column17: 21 April 2019. Raia Mutomboki Donat, Ngandu, and Mabala held a meeting. Following the meeting, the groups looted Kibilu, Shabunda. The armed group abducted 10 men as porters.

21 April 2019. Raia Mutomboki Shabani and Raia Mutomboki Butachibera clashed in Ngokwe (coordinates are approximate based on Kivu Security Tracker map), after a disagreement during a meeting between the armed groups. Three Shabani and four Butachibera combatants were killed.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 21 April 2019 (on or before). A soldier raped a pregnant woman in Katwa, Nyiragongo (no coordinates available). The perpetrator was arrested.

column6: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 21 April 2019. During the night, the FARDC intercepted an unidentified armed group as it approached their base in Jiro, Ituri. Four soldiers and one attacker were killed, although other sources report ten fatalities. Approximately $9,000 was also stolen by the combatants.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 22 April 2019. An unidentified armed group abducted ten people (including four women) from Kiwanja, Rutshuru.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 22 April 2019. An unidentified armed group abducted approximately six people in Kahunga, Rutshuru. Most of the abductees were reportedly women. The body of a male abductee, with bullet wounds, was discovered the following day.

22 April 2019. The FNL ambushed a bus in Kahwizi (aka Muhungu), as it was traveling from Bukavu to Uvira. The assailants assaulted the driver and looted the passengers. They also set the bus, as well as a civilian's motorcycle on fire.
22 April 2019. Students from the Pedagogical Institute in Bukavu demonstrated against additional fees added by the institution. The demonstrators barricaded roads in Bukavu. [size=no report]

column6: FNL-N: National Forces of Liberation (Nzabampema Faction)
column17: 22-25 April 2019. Approximately 200 FNL-Nzabampema combatants were observed in the mountain ranges of Kamombo, Karumyo, and Nyarusanze of Fizi.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 22 April 2019. A Mayi Mayi group ambushed an FARDC convoy along the Fizi-Mwenga road, near Kakamba, Fizi (no coordinates available).

column7: Prisoners (Democratic Republic of Congo); Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-) Prison Guards
column17: 22 April - 06 May 2019. Prisoners took control of the central prison of Kananga and refused access to guards and administrators into the facility. During the night of 06/05, an unknown number escaped the prison, including Kamonia Nsapu elements. The suspects on trial for the murder of the UN experts were also among the escapees. Those who remained continued to prevent prison officials from entering the facility. [size=no report]

22 April 2019. Angolan military forces entered Kiphese, Lukula (no coordinates available). The security forces were searching for FLEC rebels. During their incursions, which occurred at least twice during April, the forces detained at least four people who they took back to Angola.

column9: Batwa Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 23 April 2019 (on or before). The FARDC Sokola II operation advanced to Magunda, Mwenga in their pursuit of FNL and FOREBU forces. Locals worry that the military is pushing the armed groups further into Mwenga.
24 April 2019. Health professionals demonstrated in Butembo against violence targeting the Ebola response. [size=dozens]

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Civilians (International); Health Workers (Democratic Republic of Congo); MSF: Doctors Without Borders

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
